125.01  POSITION OF ASSISTANT DIRECTOR ESTABLISHED.
   Council hereby establishes the position of Assistant Director of Finance.
(Ord. 1992-070.  Passed 3-24-92.)
125.02  DUTIES OF ASSISTANT DIRECTOR.
   The duties of the Assistant Director of Finance are:
   (a)   Under the direction of the Director of Finance to perform the duties
as may be required by the Director as an assistant to the Director.
   (b)   In the absence of the Director of Finance to perform all of the
functions and duties of the Director of Finance as required by the laws of
Ohio, the Charter of Eastlake and ordinances of Council.
      (Ord. 1992-071.  Passed 3-24-92.)
125.03  FEES FOR PROPERTY VACATING.
   From time to time the City may vacate property it deems no longer usable to
the City.  The property owner(s) who obtain the vacated property shall pay all
normal and reasonable costs associated with the vacating of the property
including, but not limited to, all engineering fees, surveying costs if
required, and transfer fees.
(Ord. 1992-173.  Passed 10-13-92.)
125.04  CERTIFICATION FEES OF ASSESSMENTS.
   A charge of five dollars ($5.00) per parcel of real estate shall be
collected by the Director of Finance for certification of future special
assessments on any such parcel or for certification that no special assessments
have been levied on any such parcel.  The Director of Finance is not required
to make a certification with respect to any parcel without first receiving a
written request for the same and payment of the charge.
(Ord. 2017-045.  Passed 5-23-17.)
125.05  COLLECTION OF FEES.
   The following fees shall be collected in advance by the Director of
Finance.  Upon receipt of any such fee, notification shall be given to the
proper board.
 
(a)   Application for rezoning, including
   docketing, publication costs, hearing  $225.00
   and all other items
(b)   Planning Commission application,
   including docketing, publication costs,180.00
   hearing and all other items
(c)   Renewal of conditional use permits f  35.00
   a period of one year
(d)   Renewal of conditional use permits f  70.00
   a period of three years
(e)   Appeals to Zoning Board of Appeals  150.00
(f)   Codified Ordinances Book            200.00
(g)   Full-color Zone Map                   10.00
      (Ord. 2011-016.  Passed 2-22-11.)
125.06  COPIES OF PUBLIC RECORDS; FEES.
   All public records of the City, as defined in Ohio R.C. 149.43, shall be
open for inspection at reasonable times during the normal work week.  Upon
request, a person responsible for public records shall make copies at a cost of
five cents (5¢) per 1-side page, and copies will be made within a reasonable
period of time.
(Ord. 2015-063.  Passed 8-11-15.)
125.07  PREVAILING WAGE COORDINATOR.
   In compliance with Ohio R.C. 4115.071, there is hereby established the
position of Prevailing Wage Coordinator.  In addition to the duties of
Prevailing Wage Coordinator, this position shall also include being the City's
Income Tax Investigator and Workers' Compensation Claim Inspector. 
(Ord. 1992-062.  Passed 3-10-92.)
125.08  PETTY CASH AND CHANGE FUND.
   (a)   The Director of Finance is hereby empowered to maintain a Petty Cash
Fund in an amount not to exceed one thousand one hundred seventy-five dollars
($1,175) to be broken down as follows:
 
Finance Department $  50.00
Service Department     25.00
Police Department  1,100.00
Total              $1,175.00
(Ord. 2010-036.  Passed 5-25-10.)
   (b)   The Director of Finance is hereby empowered to maintain a change fund
in an amount not to exceed five thousand nine hundred dollars ($5,900), with
said funds to be expended as determined appropriate by the Finance Director.
(Ord. 2015-005.  Passed 1-27-15.)
125.09  FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE.
   To further assist City Council with a complete financial accounting, the
City Finance Director shall supply to Council the following:
   (a)   A copy of monthly printouts, by department, of the master
requisitions/payments, along with the Monthly Financial Expenditures and
Revenue Report.
   (b)   On a monthly basis, a copy of the most recent bank reconciliation for
any and all accounts held by the City with banking institutions.
   (c)   On an annual basis, a five-year financial forecast and five-year
capital expenditure plan.  This information will be provided on or before the
thirtieth (30th) day of November of each year with the annual estimate of
revenues and expenditures for the succeeding year.  (Ord. 2008-017.  Passed 3-
25-08.)
125.10  CHARGE FOR BAD CHECKS.
   No person shall issue a bad check to the City in payment of an obligation to
the City which is returned by the payor’s bank marked “insufficient funds”,
“payment  stopped”, “account closed”, or in any other way is not a good check. 
In addition to any other penalty provided by law or other sections of the
Codified Ordinances or statutes of the State of Ohio, the person issuing such a
bad check shall be subject to a charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each
bad check issued in favor of and submitted to the City.
(Ord. 2004-033.  Passed 4-13-04.)
125.11  EXPENDITURE LIMITATION.
   (a)   The Mayor or the respective department head is hereby authorized to
make purchases and expenditures for any department of the Municipality for
materials, supplies, equipment, labor or related items, said purchases or
expenditures not to exceed the amount of twenty-five thousand dollars
($25,000), per purchase, contract or expenditure, provided that Council has
appropriated sufficient sums for said purchase, contract or expenditure. 
Notwithstanding the foregoing, in the case of a real and present emergency, the
Mayor or respective department head may make such purchase, contract or
expenditure and provided good faith efforts are used to secure the lowest and
best provider.  No such purchase, contract or expenditure in excess of twenty-
five thousand dollars ($25,000) shall be authorized without the approval of
Council, and shall otherwise be made in accordance with the provisions of
Article X, Section 6 of the Charter.
   (b)   No agreement, contract and/or grant that will or likely may generate
revenue in excess of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000) shall be made
without the authorization of Council.
   (c)   Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions in this Section
125.11, with regards to any utility service consumed by the City, including gas
or electric service, the Director of Finance may, with the approval of the
Mayor, make purchase, contract or expenditure for such utility service provider
and provided good faith efforts are used to secure the lowest and best
provider.
(Ord. 2017-046.  Passed 5-13-17.)
125.12  SALE AND DISPOSITION OF PERSONAL PROPERTY.
   (a)   Municipal personal property, with the exception of municipally owned
automobiles, not needed for municipal purposes, the estimated value of which is
less than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500), may be sold by the
officer having supervision or management of that property.  If the estimated
value of that property is two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500) or more,
it shall be sold only when authorized by an ordinance of the legislative
authority of the municipal corporation and approved by the board, officer or
director having supervision or management of that property.  When so
authorized, the board, officer or director shall make said sale in accordance
with Section 721.15 of the Ohio Revised Code.
   (b)   If the officer having supervision or management of municipal personal
property determines that municipal personal property is not needed for public
use, or is obsolete or unfit for the use for which it was acquired, and that
the property has no value, the officer may discard or salvage that property.
   (c)   The sale or disposition of municipal personal property as provided in
this section shall be made in accordance with a written policy adopted by the
officer having supervision or management of said property with said policy
approved by the Director of Finance.
(Ord. 2007-039.  Passed 4-10-07.)
125.13  NON-COMPETITIVE BID PROCEDURE FOR THE SALE OF PUBLIC REAL PROPERTY NOT
NEEDED FOR ANY PUBLIC PURPOSE.
   (a)   If a buyer interested in property that may be turned into an immediate
economic benefit to the City, above and beyond the sale price, presents a
signed purchase agreement to the Director of Finance, along with a current
property appraisal prepared by a State certified real property appraiser and a
title report in support of the offer, and said purchase agreement contains a
condition that any sale pursuant to it shall result in submission of a
development plan and commitment to commence construction within six (6) months
or some greater time as Council may approve, and, if not complied with, will
cause a refund of the purchase price and reverter of the real property to the
City, and so long as the amount of real property being acquired is less than
(10) ten acres, then the Council may agree, without competitive bidding, to
accept the purchase agreement or modify the purchase agreement for acceptance
by purchaser so long as Council by ordinance identifies the time sensitive
nature of the development and of the economic benefit to be gained by prompt
action to conclude the transaction.
   (b)   Any such ordinance shall be fully and distinctly read on three
different days.  Any such ordinance having been fully read on its first reading
may be read by title only on second and third reading.  (Ord. 2015-029.  Passed
4-14-15.)
CHAPTER 126
Municipal Income Tax
126.01   Duty to receive tax imposed.
126.02   Duty to enforce collection.
126.03   Authority to make and enforce regulations.
126.04   Authority to arrange installment payments.
126.05   Authority to determine amount of tax due.
126.06   Authority to make investigations.
126.07   Authority to compel production of records.
126.08   Refusal to produce records.
126.09   Confidential nature of information obtained.
126.10   Taxpayer required to retain records.
126.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Taxation and finances - see CHTR. Art.
X, Sec.
8
Municipal income taxes - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 718
Income tax - see ADM. Ch.
183
126.01  DUTY TO RECEIVE TAX IMPOSED.
   It shall be the duty of the Tax Administrator to receive the tax imposed by
this chapter in the manner prescribed herein from the taxpayers; to keep an
accurate record thereof, and to report all moneys so received.
(Ord. 1995-131.  Passed 6-13-95.)
126.02  DUTY TO ENFORCE COLLECTION.
   It shall be the duty of the Tax Administrator to enforce payment of all
taxes owing to the City, to keep accurate records for a minimum of five years
showing the amount due from each taxpayer required to file a declaration and
make any return, or both, including taxes withheld, and to show the dates and
amounts of payments thereof.
(Ord. 1995-131.  Passed 6-13-95.)
126.03  AUTHORITY TO MAKE AND ENFORCE REGULATIONS.
   The Tax Administrator is hereby charged with the enforcement of the
provisions of this chapter and is hereby empowered, subject to the approval of
the Board of Review, to adopt and promulgate and to enforce rules and
regulations relating to any matter or thing pertaining to the collection of
taxes and the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this chapter,
including provisions for the reexamination and correction of returns.
(Ord. 1995-131.  Passed 6-13-95.)
126.04  AUTHORITY TO ARRANGE INSTALLMENT PAYMENTS.
   The Tax Administrator is authorized to arrange for the payment of unpaid
taxes, interest and penalties on a schedule of installment payments, when the
taxpayer has proved to the Tax Administrator that, due to certain hardship
conditions, he is unable to pay the full amount of the tax due.  Such
authorization shall not be granted until proper returns are filed by the
taxpayer for all amounts owed by him under this chapter.
   Failure to make any deferred payment when due shall cause the total unpaid
amount, including penalty and interest, to become payable on demand and the
provisions of Section
126.99 shall apply.
(Ord. 1995-131.  Passed 6-13-95.)
126.05  AUTHORITY TO DETERMINE AMOUNT OF TAX DUE.
   In any case where a taxpayer has failed to file a return or has filed a
return which does not show the proper amount of tax due, the Tax Administrator
may determine the amount of tax appearing to be due the City from the taxpayer
and shall send to such taxpayer a written statement showing the amount of tax
so determined together with interests and penalties thereon, if any.
(Ord. 1995-131.  Passed 6-13-95.)
126.06  AUTHORITY TO MAKE INVESTIGATIONS.
   The Tax Administrator, or any authorized employee, is hereby authorized to
examine the books, papers, records and federal income tax returns of any
employer or of any taxpayer or person subject to, or whom the Tax Administrator
believes is subject to, the provisions of this chapter, for the purpose of
verifying the accuracy of any return made or, if no return was made, to
ascertain the tax due under this chapter.  Every such employer, supposed
employer, taxpayer or supposed taxpayer is hereby directed and required to
furnish upon written request by the Tax Administrator, or his duly authorized
agent or employee, the means, facilities and opportunity for making such
examinations and investigations as are hereby authorized.
(Ord. 1995-131.  Passed 6-13-95.)
126.07  AUTHORITY TO COMPEL PRODUCTION OF RECORDS.
   The Tax Administrator is hereby authorized to order any person presumed to
have knowledge of the facts to appear before him and may examine such person,
under oath, concerning any income which was or should have been returned for
taxation or any transaction tending to affect such income, and for this purpose
may compel the production of books, papers, records and federal income tax
returns and the attendance of all persons before him, whether as parties or
witnesses, whenever he believes such persons have knowledge of such income or
information pertinent to such inquiry.
(Ord. 1995-131.  Passed 6-13-95.)
126.08  REFUSAL TO PRODUCE RECORDS.
   The refusal to produce books, papers, records and federal income tax
returns, or the refusal to submit to such examination by any employer or
persons subject or presumed to be subject to the tax or by any officer, agent
or employee of a person subject to the tax or required to withhold tax or the
failure of any person to comply with the provisions of this chapter or with an
order or subpoena of the Tax Administrator hereby authorized shall be deemed a
violation of this chapter, punishable as provided in Section
126.99.
(Ord. 1995-131.  Passed 6-13-95.)
126.09  CONFIDENTIAL NATURE OF INFORMATION OBTAINED.
   Any information gained as a result of any returns, investigations, hearings
or verifications required or authorized by this chapter shall be confidential
except for official purposes, or except in accordance with proper judicial
order.  No person shall divulge such information.
(Ord. 1995-131.  Passed 6-13-95.)
126.10  TAXPAYER REQUIRED TO RETAIN RECORDS.
   Every taxpayer shall retain all records necessary to compute his tax
liability for a period of five years from the date his return is filed, or with
withholding taxes are paid.
(Ord. 1995-131.  Passed 6-13-95.)
126.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever:
      (1)   Fails, neglects or refuses to make any return or declaration
required by this chapter; or
      (2)   Makes any incomplete, false or fraudulent return; or
      (3)   Willfully fails, neglects or refuses to pay the tax, penalties or
interest imposed by this chapter; or
      (4)   Willfully fails, neglects or refuses to withhold the tax from his
employee or to remit such withholding to the Tax Administrator; or
      (5)   Refuses to permit the Tax Administrator or any duly authorized
agent or employee to examine his books, records, papers and federal income tax
returns relating to the income or net profits of a taxpayer; or
      (6)   Fails to appear before the Tax Administrator and to produce his
books, records, papers or federal income tax returns relating to the income or
net profits of a taxpayer upon order or subpoena of the Tax Administrator; or
      (7)   Refuses to disclose to the Tax Administrator any information with
respect to the income or net profits of a taxpayer; or
      (8)   Fails to comply with the provisions of this chapter or any order or
subpoena of the Tax Administrator authorized hereby; or
      (9)   Gives to an employer false information as to his true name, correct
social security number and residence address, or fails to promptly notify an
employer of any change in residence address and date thereof; or
      (10)   Fails to use ordinary diligence in maintaining proper records of
employees' residence addresses, total wages paid and the City's income tax
withheld, or knowingly gives the Tax Administrator false information; or
      (11)   Attempts to do anything whatsoever to avoid the payment of the
whole or any part of the tax, penalties or interest imposed by this chapter; or
      (12)   Fails to comply with the confidential requirements as spelled out
by Section
126.09;
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree and shall be fined not
more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) and/or imprisoned not more than six
months or both for each offense.
   (b)   Prosecutions for an offense made punishable under this section or any
other provision of this chapter shall be commenced within three years after the
commission of the offense, provided that in the case of fraud, failure to file
a return, or the omission of twenty-five percent (25%) or more of income
required to be reported, prosecutions may be commenced within six years after
the commission of the offense.
   (c)   The failure of any employer or person to receive or procure a return,
declaration or other required form shall not excuse him from making any
information return, return or declaration, from filing such form or from paying
the tax.
(Ord. 1995-131.  Passed 6-13-95.)

Department of Public Service

127.01  DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SERVICE ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby created a Department of Public Service for the purpose of
constructing, maintaining and repairing roads, streets, highways, sewers,
drains, ditches, lighting, bridges, sidewalks, signs and for other services
usually provided by such a department.  The Department of Public Service shall
consist of such employees as Council shall from time to time authorize, and
shall on a biweekly basis report to Council on its activities, and shall in
brief, report the status of all new or existing projects undertaken by
contracting engineers or engineering firms employed by the City.
(Ord. 1983-051.  Passed 3-15-83.)
127.02  RULES AND REGULATIONS; VIOLATIONS.
   (a)   The Director of Public Service is authorized to make rules and
regulations for the control, management and operation of the sewage disposal
system.  Such rules shall be deemed in effect after five days' posting in the
five public places designated by Council for the posting of ordinances in
Section
113.01.
   (b)   No person shall knowingly violate any rule or regulation of the
Director of Public Service in the management, operation and control of the
sewage disposal system.
(Ord. 1983-051.  Passed 3-15-83.)
127.03  SEWERS AND INSPECTION DIVISION ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby established a Division of Sewers and Inspection within and
under the control of the Department of Public Service.
(Ord. 1983-051.  Passed 3-15-83.)
127.04  CONTRACT ALTERATIONS OR MODIFICATIONS.
   When, in the opinion of the Director of Public Service, it becomes
necessary, in the prosecution of any work or improvement under contract, to
make alterations or modifications in the contract, such alterations or
modifications shall only be made upon the order of the Director, but such order
shall have no effect until the price, not exceeding two thousand five hundred
dollars ($2,500), to be paid for the work and material, or both, under the
altered or modified contract, has been agreed upon in writing and signed on
behalf of the City by the Mayor and Director of Finance.  No contractor may
recover anything for work or material because of any such alteration or
modification unless the contract is made or modified in such manner, nor shall
he be allowed to recover for such work and material, or either, more than the
agreed price or, if on a unit basis, more than the total quantity of units
furnished by such contractor.  In all other respects the law relating to the
requiring of bids and awarding of contracts for such improvements, so far as it
has application, shall remain in full effect.
(Ord. 1983-051.  Passed 3-15-83.)
127.05  CHARGES FOR SERVICE AND EQUIPMENT.
   Where services are performed or equipment furnished by the Department of
Public Service to other departments of the City, other political subdivisions
and persons, firms and corporations, the following charges shall be collected:
 
Equipment Used                        Charge Per Hour Excluding Operator
Grader                                $48.00
Street sweeper                        40.00
Sewer cleaning equipment              65.00
Compressor                            20.00
Truck                                 25.00
Loader                                48.00
Chain saw                             20.00
Tar kettle                            40.00
Water pump                            18.00
Mower                                 25.00
Salt spreader tuck                    60.00
Backhoe                               45.00
Pickup truck (litter control program) 20.00 per day
Barricade lanterns and flares         10.00 each per day
   may be rented for
      
 
Labor                                  Charge Per Hour
Operator                               $13.65 - 21.00
Supervisory (Assistant Foreman and Up) 20.00 - 30.00
Engineers                              65.00
 
   All materials used shall be billed at cost plus thirty percent (30%).  No
equipment shall be used unless authorized by the Director of Public Service.
(Ord. 1988-077.  Passed 5-10-88.)
127.06  DIRECTOR TO BE BRIDGE INSPECTOR.
   The Director of Public Service is hereby established as the Inspector of
Bridges in accordance with Ohio R.C. 723.54.  He is directed to perform the
function of Bridge Inspector as the functions are described in Ohio R.C. 723.54
and in accordance with the Manual of Bridge Inspection described in Ohio R.C.
5501.47.
(Ord. 1983-051.  Passed 3-15-83.)
127.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever knowingly violates any rule or regulation of the Director of Public
Service authorized under this chapter shall be, for a first offense, fined not
more than fifty dollars ($50.00), and for a second or subsequent offense not
more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 1983-051.  Passed 3-15-83.)

129.01  RESIDENCE REQUIREMENT FOR DIRECTOR WAIVED.
   The residence requirement for the Director of Public Safety as set forth in
Ohio R.C. 737.01 is hereby waived, effective retroactively to February 1, 1972.
(Ord. 1972-122.  Passed 8-22-72.)
129.02  SCHOOL GUARDS:  APPOINTMENT; COMPENSATION; DUTIES.
   There is hereby created the position of school guard who shall be paid
compensation at the rate provided in Chapter
155.  The school guards shall be appointed by the Mayor and shall be under the
supervision of the Department of Public Safety.  The persons appointed shall
perform the general duties required in guarding and protecting school children
crossing roadways and intersections and shall perform such other duties in
connection therewith as may be assigned.  In the selection of appointees for
the positions, first consideration shall be given to older residents of the
area of the City in which the duties are to be performed and the appointees
shall live in the area of the place of assigned duty.
(Ord. 1972-193.  Passed 12-12-72.)
129.03  ALARM SYSTEMS; PERMITS; FEES; MONITORING SERVICE FUND.
   (a)   Authority to Install Alarms.  A business or residence located within
the City may be equipped with an alarm system for the purpose of detecting and
signaling an unauthorized intrusion, the presence of smoke or fire, or a
medical emergency, only upon compliance with the provisions hereinafter set
forth.  Pre-existing alarms or installations are subject to the requirements
set forth herein.
   (b)   Permit Required.  A permit shall be required for any alarm system
installed under subsection (a) hereof and defined in subsection (c) hereof. 
The permit shall be issued by the Safety Director after approval by the Chief
of Police or the Fire Chief and after payment of all applicable fees.  The
owner/resident of the business/residence wherein the alarm is installed shall
be responsible for obtaining the alarm permit.
   (c)   Alarm Types.  The following alarm types are subject to subsections (a)
and (b) hereof and are defined as follows:
      (1)   Police and fire alarms are those alarms which are connected
directly to the police and fire alarm panels through leased lines from the
premises protected.
      (2)   Central station alarms are those alarms which are connected to a
private alarm company by various means from protected premises.
      (3)   Local alarms are those alarms which sound a bell, horn, buzzer or
other type of audible signal, as the principal means of summoning assistance. 
Whenever an audible device is used in residential areas or adjacent areas, an
automatic shut-off not to exceed five minutes, shall be utilized on the audible
portion of the alarm.
      (4)   Dialer alarms are those alarms which use an automatic telephone
dialer to summon assistance in case of burglary, fire or medical emergency. 
When installed under subsection (a) and (b) hereof they may be programmed for
the special dialer line.
   (d)   False Alarms.
      (1)   Definition:  A false alarm occurs when the alarm system is
actuated, the Police or Fire Divisions are dispatched and discover no obvious
cause for the alarm, or the alarm subscriber has accidentally or erroneously
activated the system.
      (2)   A charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be assessed for each
false alarm that is reported by the Police or Fire Division.
      (3)   No charge shall be made for the first false alarm in any month.
      (4)   Any charge for a false alarm, as defined in subsection (d)(1)
hereof which remains unpaid for thirty days after the date of invoice shall
result in penalties as prescribed under Section
129.99.
   (e)   Equipment Regulations.
      (1)   All alarm equipment installed in the City shall meet the applicable
standards of the Underwriters' Laboratories, the National Fire Protection
Association or other recognized industry standards.
      (2)   The sensory mechanism used in connection with such devices shall be
adjusted to suppress false indications of fire or intrusion, so that the device
will not be actuated by impulses due to transient pressure change in water
pipes, short flashes of light, wind noises adjacent to the installation or
other forces unrelated to genuine alarms.
      (3)   All components comprising such device shall be maintained by the
owner or lessee in good repair to assure reliability of operation.
      (4)   Each alarm equipment supplier that sells, installs or leases an
automatic protection device shall furnish instructions as to the way the device
operates, along with maintenance instructions, to the subscriber.
      (5)   Each alarm equipment supplier that sells, or leases to a person an
automatic protection device which is installed on such person's premises in the
City for which a permit is required shall provide for receiving calls for
service, directly or through an agent, on a twenty-four hour basis, seven days
a week and shall respond to such calls within eight hours of the time they are
received.
      (6)   At the time of installation, each alarm equipment supplier shall
furnish to the person for whom an automatic protection device has been
installed, written information as to how service can be obtained at any time,
including the telephone number to call for service.
      (7)   The Chief of Police and the Fire Chief or any other officer
designated by them shall have the authority, at reasonable times and upon oral
notice, to enter upon any premises within the City, to inspect the installation
and operation of an automatic protection device or signaling device, the
purpose of which is to report an emergency to the police and/or fire station.
   (f)   Permit Fees; Installation Fees; Alarm Monitoring Fees.
      (1)   Permit fees.  The permit fee for all alarm types as defined in
subsection (c) hereof shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
      (2)   Installation and alarm monitoring fees.
         A.   The installation and monitoring fee for police and fire alarms as
defined in subsection (c)(1) hereof is two hundred forty dollars ($240.00),
initially, and an annual fee thereafter of one hundred twenty dollars ($120.00)
for alarm monitoring.  The initial installation fee is applied as follows:
            $50.00, cost of alarm module; $45.00, cost of technical
connections; $25.00, cost of new alarm monitoring equipment; $120.00, annual
alarm monitoring fee.  If the initial installation requires more than a one-
hour time period, an additional charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per hour
will apply.
            A separate fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for the first hour,
and twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per hour thereafter shall be charged for
technical service/repair calls after initial installation.
            The monitoring fee shall extend from January 1 to December 31.  If
a permit is issued within the calendar year, the monitor fee shall be prorated
in accordance with the number of months left in the year at the rate of ten
dollars ($10.00) per month.
            If the annual monitoring fee is not remitted to the Division of
Police prior to December 31 of each year, the service shall be discontinued.
         B.   The installation and monitoring fee for dialer alarms as defined
in subsection (c) hereof shall be as follows:  the installation fee shall be
one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) and an annual monitoring fee of one hundred
twenty dollars ($120.00).
            The monitoring fee shall extend from January 1 to December 31.  If
a permit is issued within the calendar year, the monitor fee shall be prorated
in accordance with the number of months left in year at the rate of ten dollars
($10.00) per month.  If the annual monitoring fee is not remitted to the
Division of Police prior to December 31 of each year, the service shall be
discontinued.
      (3)   False alarm fees.  See subsection (d)(2).
   (g)   Revocation of Permit; Right of Appeal.  For violation of this section
for failure to properly maintain an installation or when the number of false
alarms for any installation equals fifteen in any twelve-month period, the
Chief of Police and/or Fire Chief shall serve written notice upon a permit
holder of the intent to revoke the permit.  Such notice shall be given not less
than seven days prior to revocation.  Such notice shall state the right of the
permit holder to appeal to the Safety Director.  If an appeal is filed in
writing the Safety Director shall hold a hearing on the matter and shall render
a decision on the basis of the facts presented.  The Safety Director's
decisions shall be final.  In the event no appeal is filed, the Chief of Police
and/or the Fire Chief shall transmit all pertinent information to the Safety
Director who shall cancel the permit.  The Chief of Police and/or Fire Chief
shall take whatever steps are necessary to disconnect the alarms.
   (h)   Liability of City.  The issuance of any permit in conjunction with
this section shall not constitute acceptance by the City of any liability to
maintain any equipment, to answer any alarms or for any claim in connection
therewith.  On the face of the permit, there shall be a waiver of any claim
against the City.
   (i)   Rules and Regulations.  The Safety Director or his authorized
representative shall make and enforce such rules and regulations as he may deem
necessary for the enforcement of the provisions hereof, and for the proper
determination and collection of the fees and charges herein provided.
   (j)   Required Alarms.
      (1)   The following terms have the meanings as set forth herein:
         A.   "Local alarm system" means that system producing signals at one
or more places on the premises served.
         B.   "Central station system" means a system or group of systems, the
operation of which is signaled to, recorded in, maintained and supervised from
an approved central station, in which there are competent and experienced
observers and operators in attendance at all times whose duty it shall be, upon
receipt of a signal, to take such action as shall be required under the rules
established for their guidance.  Such systems are independently owned,
controlled and operated by a person, firm or corporation whose principal
business is the furnishing and maintaining of supervised protective signaling
service and who has no interest in the protected properties.
      (2)   The following are required to connect to local and central station
fire alarm systems:
         A.   All multi-family dwellings in excess of four stories.
         B.   All establishments, both public and private, to which a fee is
paid for providing rest or nursing care for the elderly.
         C.   All schools, and public assembly buildings exceeding 5,000 square
feet.
         D.   All manufacturing, commercial and mercantile buildings in excess
of 12,000 square feet total of all floors.
         E.   All other buildings, dwellings or structures so determined in the
future by Council.
         F.   It shall be the responsibility of the owner of each new building
described in this section to comply, effective immediately.
         G.   It shall be the responsibility of the owner of all existing
buildings described in this section to comply, effective six months from the
passage of this section, and/or at the time of any change of ownership and/or
occupancy, whichever occurs first, effective immediately.
   (k)   Alarm Monitoring Service Fund.  There is hereby established a special
fund under the authority of Ohio R.C. 5705.09(F), which shall be known as the
Alarm Monitoring Service Fund and which shall be under the supervision and
accountability of the Director of Finance.  All fees accruing to the City from
the Alarm Monitoring Service shall be deposited in the Alarm Monitoring Service
Fund.  Appropriations from the Fund shall be for the following purposes only:
      (1)   For the purchase, repair or replacement of communications
equipment;
      (2)   For the purchase and/or replacement of uniforms of the police and
fire dispatching personnel.
      (3)   For the purchase and/or replacement of new alarm monitoring
equipment.
         (Ord.  1999-011.  Passed 1-12-99.)
129.04  JUVENILE BUREAU; ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby established a Juvenile Bureau within the Department of
Public Safety.  The Bureau shall operate within the framework of the Police
Division and be under the supervision of the Chief of Police and Director of
Public Safety.
(Ord. 1973-188.  Passed 11-13-73.)
129.05  AUXILIARY POLICE UNIT; ESTABLISHED; FUND; APPLICATIONS; DUTIES.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE:  This section was repealed by Ordinance 1996-111, passed
April 8, 1996.  See Section
131.15 for relevant provisions.)
129.06  VEHICLE ACQUISITION AND OPERATION.
   (a)   Purpose.  This section is intended to define certain parameters as to
the acquisition and operation of motor vehicles by the City.  It shall apply to
all police, fire and building automobiles.
   (b)   Police Vehicle Complement.
      (1)   Patrol.  To obtain maximum efficiency, patrol vehicles should be
available so that one vehicle shall be driven by only three patrolmen, one on
each shift.  Each time the first of three additional patrolmen is added,
another patrol vehicle shall be acquired.
         There shall be two patrol vehicles available for the use of the
sergeant and lieutenant.
         In order that preventative maintenance can be performed and breakdowns
handled, one back-up unit shall be available for every ten units.
      (2)   Staff.  Four unmarked staff vehicles shall be maintained, one for
the Chief of Police, one for the Juvenile Bureau and two for the Detective
Bureau.
   (c)   Fire Vehicle Complement.  Two marked automobiles shall be maintained,
one for the Fire Chief and one for the Fire Prevention Bureau.
   (d)   Building Vehicle Complement.  Two marked automobiles shall be
maintained, one for the Chief Building Official and one for each building
inspector.
   (e)   Administration Vehicles.  Whenever possible and within the limits of
the budget of the City, a car shall be provided for the following:
      Mayor
      Director of Public Safety
      Director of Public Service
      Director of Finance
      Director of Recreation
   (f)   Changes in Vehicle Complement.  From time to time the complement of
police staff, fire cars or building cars may need to be revised.  Any such
revision shall be recommended by the Director of Public Safety and shall
require Council approval.
   (g)   Replacement Policy.  Under normal circumstances, six new patrol cars
shall be purchased to go into service in January of each year.
   (h)   Surveillance Vehicles.  Occasionally through criminal cases, the
Police Division may acquire unmarked vehicles which can be utilized for
surveillance or undercover purposes.  These vehicles shall not be considered
part of the normal police vehicle complement.
   (i)   Status Report.  Twice each year in June and December, the Director of
Public Safety shall present to Council a status report of all vehicles in the
Department fleet.  This report shall include the number, make, year and
odometer reading of each vehicle.  At this time the Director shall report on
the anticipated need for additional vehicles for appropriation purposes for the
year.
(Ord. 1983-152.  Passed 7-12-83.)
   (j)   Use of Department Vehicles..  All vehicles owned or leased by the City
shall be used solely in the course of duties of City employment.
   Only the following employees of the City are permitted to take City vehicles
home:
      Mayor
      Director of Finance
      Director of Public Safety
      Director of Public Service
      Director of Recreation
      Chief of Police
      Chief of Fire
(Ord. 1984-048.  Passed 3-13-84.)
129.07  CANINE UNIT.
   There is hereby established a Canine Unit within the Department of Public
Safety.  The Canine Unit shall operate within the framework of the Police
Division and be under the supervision of the Chief of Police and Director of
Public Safety.
(Ord. 1997-043.  Passed 3-25-97.)
129.08  RESPONSE TO EMERGENCY CALLS OUTSIDE CITY.
   (a)   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 9.60 and 737.041, Council hereby authorizes the
Director of Public Safety, the Chiefs of Police and Fire Divisions and the
officers on duty in charge of the Police and Fire Divisions to render the
services of those Divisions to other municipalities, townships, counties or the
State in times of emergency, whether or not the City has entered into mutual
aid contracts for police or fire services with any of those political
subdivisions or the State.  The determination of "times of emergency" shall be
made only by the Director of Public Safety, the Chiefs of the Police and Fire
Divisions or the officers on duty in charge of the Police and Fire Divisions,
upon a call for emergency police or fire protection services by the State or
another political subdivision of this State.
   (b)   The personnel of the Police and Fire Divisions rendering emergency
services to other political subdivisions shall, as provided by State law, be
entitled to all of their usual wages and benefits, shall be covered by Workers'
Compensation and shall be immune from any liability arising from the
reasonable, good faith rendering of emergency police and fire protection
services.
(Ord. 1983-105.  Passed 5-24-83.)
129.09  LAW ENFORCEMENT TRUST FUND.
   (a)   In accordance with Ohio R.C. 2933.43, there is hereby established a
Law Enforcement Trust Fund.  All money and the proceeds of the sale of other
property, forfeited to the City pursuant to Ohio R.C. 2933.43 or pursuant to
federal law and required by law to be disposed of in another manner, shall be
credited to the Law Enforcement Trust Fund.
   (b)   The Director of Public Safety is hereby authorized to accept all
contraband or other property seized as part of a criminal investigation or
prosecution and forfeited to the City pursuant to Ohio R.C. 2933.43 or pursuant
to federal law and required to be used for law enforcement purposes, provided
that any acceptance of real estate by the Director shall be approved by
ordinance of this Council.
   Property forfeited to the City and accepted by the Director pursuant to the
above paragraph may be destroyed, or retained by the City to be used solely in
the Division of Police for law enforcement purposes, as determined by the
Director.  Property forfeited to the City may be sold, following notice, and
without appraisal, at a public auction to the highest bidder for cash, upon the
recommendation of the Director.
   (c)   If property forfeited to the City is sold pursuant to subsection (b)
hereof, the proceeds of the sale shall be disposed of in the following order:
      (1)   To the payment of the costs incurred in the forfeiture proceedings
pursuant to Ohio R.C. 2933.43.
      (2)   To the payment of the balance due on any security interest
preserved pursuant to state law.
      (3)   To the payment of any costs incurred by the Division of Police in
connection with the storage, maintenance, security and forfeiture of the
property.
      (4)   To the Law Enforcement Trust Fund.
         (Ord. 1990-131.  Passed 6-26-90.)
   (d)   The proceeds of the Law Enforcement Trust Fund shall be used only as
outlined in the Control Policy.  Such purposes include but are not limited to
the costs of prosecuting drug offenses, the costs of protracted or complex
cases that involve the payment of overtime, to provide for training of law
enforcement personnel, to pay for a pro-rated share (twenty percent (20%)) of
new accounting, to provide for federal matching funds for federal grants such
as VOCA, and to provide for the purchase of equipment for the City’s Safety
Forces, to use ten percent (10%) of the first one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000) for drug education programs such as PAL or for such other purposes
that Council determines to be appropriate.
(Ord. 2006-118.  Passed 11-14-06.)
   (e)   Any property, other than contraband that is subject to the provisions
of Ohio R.C. 2933.43 and other than property that has been lawfully seized in
relation to a violation of Ohio R.C. 2933.43 or forfeited pursuant to federal
law and required to be used for law enforcement purposes, including money,
which apparently has been lost or abandoned may be placed in the custody of the
Police Division by any person finding or recovering the same.  A member of the
Division receiving such property shall enter in a book kept for that purpose a
description of the property, the date received, the name and address of the
person from whom received and the member of the Division receiving the property
and shall furnish to such person a receipt containing the same information. 
Property so designated by the Chief of Police for that purpose and if not
claimed by the rightful owner or other person entitled to possession thereof
within that time shall be returned to the person from who it was received, an
entry to that effect shall be made in the book above described and a receipt
for the property shall be obtained from the person to whom it is delivered.
   The Division may decline to accept custody of any property for which no
suitable storage facilities are available, but may instead enter in a book kept
for that purpose a description of the property and the location where the
rightful owner or other person entitled thereto may claim possession of the
property.
(Ord. 1990-131.  Passed 6-26-90.)

   Whoever violates any provision of Section
129.03 shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor.  (Ord.  1999-012.  Passed 1-12-
99.)

131.01  COMPOSITION.
   The Police Division may consist of a Chief of Police, five (5) lieutenants,
four (4) sergeants, and not more than twenty-nine (29) police patrol officers.
(Ord. 2003-051.  Passed 3-25-03.)
131.02  CLASSIFICATION OF PATROLMEN.
   Classification of regular patrolmen may be based on the following terms:
   (a)   Step 1.
   (b)   Step 2.
   (c)   Step 3.
   Such step requirements may, however, be waived by motion of Council upon
recommendation of the Mayor in the case of any individual patrolman.
   However, the above classification shall not apply to any regular patrolman
serving in the Police Division when this section goes into effect, and such
regular patrolman shall continue to be classified as provided before this
section was amended.
(Ord. 2003-052.  Passed 3-25-03)
131.03  SPECIAL POLICEMEN.
   (a)   Special police are to be compensated at the hourly rate provided for
special police in Chapter
155 for hours worked.
   (b)   The number of special police shall be determined by the Director of
Public Safety.  The assignment of men and women to the special police unit
shall rest with the Director of Public Safety and be subject to the discretion
and control of the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 1990-229.  Passed 12-27-90.)
131.04  PROBATION PERIOD.
   The Chief of Police, lieutenants, sergeants and each regular and special
policeman shall serve such probationary periods before their final
appointments, as provided by Ohio R.C. 124.27.
(Ord. 1950-36.  Passed 5-18-50.)
131.05  POWERS AND DUTIES OF CHIEF.
   Subject to the orders and direction of the Director of Public Safety, the
Chief of Police shall be responsible for the supervision and operation of the
Police Division, and the lieutenants, sergeants and each policeman shall be
subject to the orders of the Chief of Police, provided that the Chief of
Police, lieutenants, sergeants and each regular and special policeman shall be
accountable to the Director of Public Safety.  The Chief of Police and every
other officer making an arrest or who is a witness to or has knowledge of the
commission of any felony or misdemeanor shall at all times be present at the
trial of any case against the person charged therewith.
(Ord. 1950-36.  Passed 5-18-50.)
131.06  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Director of Public Safety may prescribe rules and regulations for the
operation of the Police Division and the conduct of its members.  The rules and
regulations shall be reduced to writing, and upon being delivered personally to
the officers of the City or posting in the office of the Police Division, each
member shall be subject to the rules and regulations, and a violation thereof
shall be cause for removal or discipline under Section
131.07.
(Ord. 1950-36.  Passed 5-18-50.)
131.07  DISCIPLINARY ACTION.
   (a)   For insubordination, malfeasance, misfeasance, nonfeasance or
violation of any of the rules and regulations prescribed by the Director of
Public Safety as provided in Section
131.06, or any other cause for removal or discipline under the laws of the
State, the Director of Public Safety may suspend for a period of not more than
thirty days or remove from office the Chief of Police, lieutenants, sergeants
or any regular or special policeman.  In the event of removal or suspension,
the officer shall not be entitled to compensation from and after the date
thereof.  The cause of such suspension or removal by the Director of Public
Safety shall be filed in writing by the Director of Public Safety in accordance
with the laws of the State.
   (b)   The Chief of Police also shall have the power to suspend any member of
the Police Division under his supervision for insubordination, malfeasance,
misfeasance, nonfeasance or violation of any of the rules and regulations
prescribed by the Director of Public Safety or for any other cause for
suspension or discipline under the laws of the State.  The period of suspension
shall be for a period of not more than thirty days, during which time the
member so suspended shall not be entitled to compensation.  The cause of the
suspension by the Chief shall be filed in writing by the Chief with the
Director of Public Safety.
(Ord. 1950-36.  Passed 5-18-50.)
131.08  RECOVERED PROPERTY; RECORDS; RETURN.
   (a)   Stolen or other property recovered by members of the Police Division
shall be deposited and kept in a place designated by the Mayor.  Each article
shall be entered in a book kept for that purpose, with the name of the owner,
if ascertained, the person from whom taken, the place where found with general
circumstances, the date of its receipt and the name of the officer receiving
it.
   (b)   An inventory of all money or other property shall be given to the
party from whom taken, and in case it is not claimed by some person within
thirty days after arrest and seizure, it shall be delivered to the person from
whom taken, and to no other person, either attorney, agent, factor or clerk,
except by special order of the Mayor.
(Ord. 1956-66.  Passed 6-5-56.)
131.09  OFFICER TO SURRENDER PROPERTY; EFFECT OF NONCOMPLIANCE.
   No officer, patrolman or other member of the Police Division shall neglect
or refuse to deposit property taken or found by him in possession of a person
arrested.  Any conviction for a violation of this section shall vacate the
office of the person so convicted.
(Ord. 1956-66.  Passed 6-5-56.)
131.10  RETURNING HELD PROPERTY.
   If, within thirty days, the money or property recovered under Section
131.08 is claimed by any other person, it shall be retained by the custodian of
it until after the discharge or conviction of the person from whom it was taken
and so long as it is required as evidence in any case in court.  If the
claimant establishes to the satisfaction of the court that he is the rightful
owner, the money or property shall be restored to him; otherwise it shall be
returned to the accused person, personally, and not to any attorney, agent,
factor or clerk of such accused person, except upon special order of the Mayor
after all liens and claims in favor of the City have first been discharged and
satisfied.
(Ord. 1956-66.  Passed 6-5-56.)
131.11  SALE OF UNCLAIMED PROPERTY.
   (a)   Except as provided by Ohio R.C. 4513.62 et seq., property unclaimed
for a period of ninety days shall be sold by the Chief of Police, after giving
due notice by advertisement, published once a week for three successive weeks
in a newspaper of general circulation in the County.  Any proceeds from the
sale shall be paid to the Director of Finance and credited to the General Fund.
   (b)   Upon the sale of any unclaimed or impounded property, if any of it was
ordered removed to a place of storage or stored, or both, by or under the
direction of the Chief of Police, any expenses or charges for such removal or
storage, or both, and costs of sale, provided the same are approved by the
Chief of Police, shall first be paid from the proceeds of the sale.  Notice
shall be given by registered mail, thirty days before the date of the sale, to
the owner or mortgagee, or other lien holder, at their last known address.
   (c)   Property authorized to be sold shall be disposed of by the Chief of
Police before January 2 and July 2 during each year.
(Ord. 1956-66.  Passed 6-5-56.)
131.12  FEES FOR COPIES OF POLICE REPORTS AND PHOTOGRAPHS.
   In the Division of Police the following charges are authorized to be made
for the services enumerated:

   black and white

      Verification of criminal report 0.25 per 1-side page
      Copies of offense/incident repor0.25 per 1-side page
 
(Ord.  1997-156.  Passed 11-11-97.)
131.13  AGE REQUIREMENT FOR ORIGINAL APPOINTMENT.
   The age requirement for an original appointment to the Police Division shall
be limited to persons between the ages of twenty-one and thirty-four years,
inclusive.
(Ord. 1980-199.  Passed 10-14-80.)
131.14  CRIME PREVENTION OFFICER.
   There is hereby established a position to be known as crime prevention
officer.  The crime prevention officer shall operate within the Department of
Public Safety, the frame work of the Police Division and be under the
supervision of the Chief of Police and Director of Public Safety.
(Ord. 1988-021.  Passed 2-9-88.)
131.15  AUXILIARY POLICE UNIT; ESTABLISHED; FUND; APPLICATIONS; DUTIES.
   (a)   An Auxiliary Police Unit is hereby established consisting of the
following positions:
      (1)   One Captain.
      (2)   Twenty-nine Patrolmen.
   (b)   The Auxiliary Police shall be under the direct jurisdiction of the
Chief of Police- Director of Public Safety who may establish such rules and
regulations as he deems necessary for the reasonable regulation of the unit.
   (c)   The uniform of the Auxiliary Police Unit shall differ from the Police
Division uniform as authorized by the Chief of Police-Director of Public
Safety.
   (d)   Applications for membership in the Auxiliary Police Unit shall be made
to the Chief of Police-Director of Public Safety and shall be reviewed by the
Lieutenant assigned responsibility for the Auxiliaries.  No one shall become a
member of the unit without the final approval of the Auxiliary Captain and
Chief of Police and the Director of Public Safety.
   (e)   Basic duties of the Auxiliary Police Unit shall include traffic
control, maintaining order at special events throughout the City and other
duties as assigned by the Chief of Police- Director of Public Safety. 
(Ord. 2006-078.  Passed 9-12-06.)
   
   (f)   A fee of eleven dollars and twenty-five cents ($11.25) per hour per
man will be assessed for renters for non-City sponsored events (i.e., dances,
weddings, etc.) which are held at the Eastlake Community Center and the J.F.K.
Center.  The number of officers for an event shall be determined by the Police
Department based on the number of attendees and other factors.  The fees are to
be deposited into the General Fund.  The Police Chief - Safety Director shall
also have the option to waive any and all fees for the Auxiliary Police.
   (g)   Each Auxiliary Officer shall be compensated at the rate of nine
dollars and twenty- five cents ($9.25) per hour worked.  The Auxiliary Police
Captain will receive additional compensation of one hundred dollars ($100.00)
per month.  The Auxiliary Police Captain shall complete payroll sheets for all
of the Auxiliary Officers for hours worked and each Auxiliary will sign their
payroll sheets.  Auxiliary payroll shall be submitted to the Police Department
bi-weekly.
(Ord. 2006-098.  Passed 10-24-06.)
   (h)   The Captain of the Auxiliary Police Unit, effective January 1, 1991,
shall receive a wage of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per month to be paid from
the Eastlake Auxiliary Police Unit Trust Fund. 
(Ord.  1999-010.  Passed 1-12-99.)
131.16  FEE FOR USE OF POLICE VEHICLE.
   There is hereby established a fee for use of police vehicles.  A fee of
twenty dollars ($20.00) per hour per car is to be applicable any time a request
is granted to use police vehicle(s) in a non-emergency situation or non-
official City use.  Such request is to be submitted to the Director of Public
Safety or his duly appointed person for approval.
(Ord.  1998-013.  Passed 1-27-98.)
131.17  EXTRA DUTY EMPLOYMENT; LIABILITY.
   Eastlake Police Officers may work off duty assignments or seek secondary
and/or extra duty employment, pursuant to the guidelines established by the
Eastlake Police Department.
   The City assumes no liability for any acts or deeds of the Police Officer in
said off duty assignments or secondary and/or extra duty employment and shall
be held harmless.
(Ord. 2005-146.  Passed 12-20-05.)
131.18  FEE FOR USE OF POLICE DEPARTMENT FIRING RANGE.
   There is hereby established a fee for use of the City of Eastlake Police
Department Firing Range by municipalities as follows:
   Per 8- hour period      $250.00
   Applications for such usage shall include a release of liability and shall
be submitted to the Range Officer in Charge and approved by the Chief of
Police. On an individual basis, the Chief of Police shall hold the right to
consider request(s), other than those of Municipalities, to use the Firing
Range. Any and all proceeds will be used exclusively by the Eastlake Police
Department for repair and upkeep of the firing range.
(Ord. 2011-118. Passed 8-23-11.)
131.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates Section
131.09 shall be fined not less than twice the value of any property not
deposited as required by such section, but not more than three thousand dollars
($3,000), or imprisoned not more than one month, or both.
(Ord. 1956-66.  Passed 6-5-56.)

132.01  ESTABLISHMENT; EFFECTIVE DATE.
   There is hereby established a full-time Division of Fire, effective at 7:30
a.m. on October 4, 1981.
(Ord. 1981-161.  Passed 8-25-81.)
132.02  COMPOSITION OF THE FULL-TIME DIVISION OF FIRE.
   (a)   Composition.  The full-time Division of Fire shall be composed of the
following officer and firefighter ranks, and such other positions that Council
may, from time to time, create:
 
(1)   Fire Chief                         1
(2)   Fire Marshal                       1
(3)   Battalion Chief(s)                 3
(4)   Lieutenant                         3
(5)   Firefighters/Paramedics not less th21
 
   (b)   The Fire Marshall shall be required to work an eight-hour (8) day for
a total of a forty (40) hour workweek and shall be compensated at the rate of
Lieutenant, pursuant to the current Union contract. The rate of pay and fringe
benefits will be modified to the 2,080 hour equivalent.
   (c)   Within the limitations established by the annual appropriation
ordinance for operation of the Department, the Mayor/Safety Director shall have
the authority to appoint such part-time firefighters as are necessary to carry
out the duties and responsibilities of the Department.  The qualifications and
duties of the part-time firefighters shall be determined by the Fire Chief,
with a maximum number of part-time firefighters not to exceed one (1) per shift
.
   Part-time firefighters shall not in any capacity replace any positions of
the full-time firefighters. 
(Ord. 2010-050.  Passed 6-8-10.)
132.03  CLASSIFICATION OF FIREFIGHTERS.
   Classification of regular firefighters shall be based on the following terms
of continuous full-time service to the City in that capacity.
   (a)   Class A, over one year.
   (b)   Class B, less than one year.
(Ord. 1981-161.  Passed 8-25-81.)
132.04  APPOINTMENT OF OFFICERS AND MEN.
   Upon certification of officers and men by the Civil Service Commission, the
Director of Public Safety shall appoint officers and men to the Division of
Fire in accordance with the civil service laws of the State.
(Ord. 1981-161.  Passed 8-25-81.)
132.05  PROBATION PERIOD.
   The Chief of Fire, Battalion Chiefs, Captains, Lieutenants and each regular
full-time member shall serve such probationary periods before their final
appointments, as provided by Ohio R.C. 124.27.
(Ord. 1991-136.  Passed 7-9-91.)
132.06  ORIGINAL APPOINTMENTS.
   All present employees of the Fire Division shall be able-bodied persons and
shall reside within a ten-mile radius from Eastlake Fire Station #1.
   All newly hired employees of the Fire Division shall be able-bodied persons
and shall as a condition of their satisfactory completion of their initial hire
probationary period, reside within a ten-mile radius from Eastlake Fire Station
#1, and at the time of their original appointment shall not be under the age of
twenty-one years or over the age of thirty-one years.
(Ord. 1993-028.  Passed 2-9-93.)
132.07  POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE CHIEF.
   Subject to the orders and directions of the Director of Public Safety, the
Fire Chief shall be the head of and responsible for the efficient operation of
the Fire Division and all members of the Division and others aiding in
extinguishing any fires or in the prevention thereof or in any duties required
to be performed by them shall be subject to his discretion and control in the
performance of such duties.
(Ord. 1981-161.  Passed 8-25-81.)
132.08  FIRE INSPECTION OF PUBLIC PLACES; ORDER TO REMEDY DANGEROUS CONDITIONS.
   Under the direction of the Director of Public Safety, the Chief of the Fire
Division shall inspect or cause to be inspected the various buildings,
structures and premises, other than private homes, in the City, to ascertain
whether proper precautions have been taken for the protection of life and
property and the prevention of fires.  If he finds that conditions are caused
or permitted to exist which are dangerous and in his opinion are likely to
cause injury or loss of property or life, or a fire in any such buildings,
structures or premises so inspected he shall order the owner, tenant, person in
possession or control thereof, or the agent for the property to correct and
rectify the condition within a reasonable time, which time shall be stated in
the order, and the person so ordered shall comply with or cause the order to be
complied with, without delay.
   However, within the discretion of the inspecting officer, the time for
compliance with any order issued by him may be, by him, extended by written
order, which shall state the date to which the order is extended.
   Any order under this section may be appealed to the Director of Public
Safety and he shall, within a reasonable period of time, make a final decision
of that appeal.
(Ord. 1981-161.  Passed 8-25-81.)
132.09  OFFICERS DESIGNATED WITH POWERS TO INVESTIGATE FIRES.
   The Chief of the Division of Fire or his duly authorized representative
member of the Division, or the Chief of the Division of Police or his duly
authorized representative member are empowered to investigate fires in
accordance with Ohio R.C. 737.27 which states as follows:
Ohio R.C. 737.27  Investigation of Fires.  The legislative authority of a
municipal corporation may invest any individual of the Fire or Police
Department, and these individuals are in power, and the duty is imposed on
these individuals to be present at all  fires, investigate the cause thereof,
examine witnesses, compel the attendance of witnesses and the production of
books and papers, and to do and perform all other acts necessary to the
effective discharge of such duties, and perform all other duties as required by
State law.
   Additionally, any officer as herein spelled out, who has reasonable belief
that a building is in danger of fire may enter such building for purpose of
examination.  Such officers as herein provided, have the authority to make
arrests.  The officer shall report his proceedings to the legislative authority
at such times as are required.
(Ord. 1981-161.  Passed 8-25-81.)
132.10  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Director of Public Safety may prescribe rules and regulations for the
operation of the Fire Division and the conduct of its members.  The rules and
regulations shall be reduced to writing and upon being delivered personally to
the members of the Fire Division or posting in the office of the Fire Division
each member shall be subject to the rules and regulations, and a violation
thereof shall be cause for reduction, suspension, removal or other forms of
discipline under Section
132.11 and/or as provided by State law.
   A copy of the Rules and Regulations shall be provided to the Mayor and
Council.
(Ord. 1981-161.  Passed 8-25-81.)
132.11  DISCIPLINARY ACTION.
   (a)   Mayor; Powers.  The Mayor has the exclusive right to suspend or remove
the Chief of the Fire Division for incompetence, gross neglect of duty, gross
immorality, habitual drunkenness, failure to obey orders by the proper
authority or for any other reasonable and just cause.
   If the Chief of Fire is so suspended or removed, the Mayor shall certify
such facts together with the cause of suspension or removal to the Municipal
Civil Service Commission, which within five days from the date of receipt of
the notice shall proceed to hear such charges and render judgment therein,
which judgment may affirm, disaffirm or modify the judgment of the Mayor.  In
the event of suspension or removal the Chief shall not be entitled to
compensation from and after the effective date thereof.
   (b)   Chief of Fire; Powers.  The Chief of Fire shall have the power to
reduce, suspend, recommend the removal of, or other forms of discipline to the
Director of Public Safety of any member of the Fire Division under his
supervision for insubordination, malfeasance, misfeasance, neglect of duties,
failure of good behavior or violation of any of the rules and regulations
prescribed by the Director of Public Safety or for any cause for reduction,
suspension, recommended removal or other forms of discipline by the Chief shall
be filed in writing by the Chief with the Director of Public Safety.
(Ord. 1981-161.  Passed 8-25-81.)
132.12  FEES FOR COPIES OF FIRE REPORTS AND PHOTOGRAPHS.
   In the Division of Fire the following charges are authorized to be made for
the services enumerated:
 
For copies of accident reports:           $ 0.25 per 1-side page
For reproductions of photographs:
      8 inch by 10 inch size,          5.00 each photo
      black and white
      8 inch by 10 inch size, color    7.50 each photo
      3-1/2 inch by 5 inch size,       2.00 each photo
      black and white
      3-1/2 inch by 5 inch size, color 2.00 each photo
      Verification of fire report      0.25 per 1-side page
      Copies of accident/incident repor0.25 per 1-side page
 
(Ord.  1997-157.  Passed 11-11-97.)
132.13  POLITICAL ACTIVITIES. (REPEALED)
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
132.13 was repealed by Ordinance 2009-107, passed September 22, 2009.
132.14  FEES FOR RESCUE CALLS.
   Council and the administration of the City of Eastlake hereby authorizes the
establishment of fees for all rescue calls by the Eastlake Fire Department and
to allow the operating revenues received from contract payments and local taxes
to be used as payment of otherwise applicable co-payments and deductibles that
would otherwise be due from residents of the City of Eastlake and non-
residents.
   (a)   The City will provide ambulance and emergency rescue squad services
to  and the City shall only bill insurers of the residents of Eastlake and Non-
Residents, including the Federal Health Care Programs of Medicare and Medicaid,
for the services provided but only to the extent of their insurance coverage,
i.e. there will be no out of pocket cost to the residents of the City or the
Non-Residents.  The City shall treat the revenues received from Timberlake and
Lakeline contract payments and Eastlake local taxes as payment of any otherwise
applicable co-payments and deductibles that would otherwise be due from the
residents of the City of Eastlake and the Villages of Timberlake and Lakeline.
   (b)   The City will provide ambulance and emergency rescue squad services
in  exchange for the assignment of the insurance company proceeds available to
the non-resident user and the City will accept as full payment from non-
resident the usual and customary rates as allowed by the particular insurance
companies for the services provided.  The City will not charge or collect any
amount of money in excess of the usual, customary and reasonable (UCR)
payments, including any amounts received from Medicare and/or any Medicare
Supplemental Insurance carriers and/or Medicaid.
   (c)   The following schedule of fees or as modified shall be applicable to
individuals  who use the following services:
 
Basic Life Support Transportation    $1,100.00
Advanced Life Support Transportation $1,100.00
Advanced Life Support 2              $1,100.00
Basic Life Support Mileage           $    17.00
Advanced Life Support Mileage        $    17.00
 
   (d)   The Mayor is authorized to enter into an agreement with a company that
will provide electronic claims filing systems for the purpose of collecting
insurance proceeds indicated in subsection (c) hereof or as modified
thereafter.
   (e)   The Mayor and the Finance Director are authorized to establish
guidelines  and procedures to assist the indigent and the financially needy
that are unable to pay for the rescue squad services.
   (f)   All funds collected pursuant to this Section shall be disbursed as
follows:
      (1)   Such part thereof as is necessary to defray all expenses of
collection shall be  paid.
      (2)   The balance remaining after such payments shall be deposited in the
Fire  Department Accounts in the following manner:
         A.   Priority will be given to train and equip the special teams of
the Fire Department: water rescue team, hazardous materials team, technical
rescue team, fire investigation unit, and shall include paramedic and fire
training.  Monies will be allocated for equipment, classes, and other funding
as needed.
         B.   Any proceeds will be used exclusively by the Eastlake Fire
Department to  improve its operational capabilities as determined by the Chief
of Fire and/or the Safety Director of the City of Eastlake.
            (Ord. 2011-159.  Passed 12-13-11.)

135.01  CHIEF BUILDING OFFICIAL.
   The position of Chief Building Official shall be appointed by the Mayor and
subject to a two-thirds confirmation of all the members of Council, and he
shall perform such duties as may be assigned to him from time to time by the
Mayor and/or Director of Public Safety.  He may be removed from office by the
Mayor, and such removal shall not take place without the concurrence of two-
thirds of all the members of Council.
(Ord. 1992-063.  Passed 3-10-92.)
135.02  INSPECTORS I.
   There are hereby established within the Division of Inspections the
following positions:
   (a)   A state certified Electrical Inspector shall be appointed by the
Director of Public Safety.
   (b)   A state certified Plumbing Inspector shall be appointed by the
Director of Public Safety.
   Inspectors I shall have a general knowledge of the building trades in
addition to their specialization in the electrical or plumbing field, and shall
perform such duties as may be directed by the Chief Building Official.
(Ord. 1990-198.  Passed 11-13-90.)
135.03  INSPECTORS II.
   There are hereby established within the Division of Inspections the
following positions.
   Inspectors II shall have a general knowledge of the building and
construction trades.
   Inspectors II shall be appointed by the Director of Public Safety and shall
perform such duties as directed by the Chief Building Official.
(Ord. 1990-199.  Passed 11-13-90.)
135.04  INSPECTORS III.
   There are hereby established within the Division of Inspections the
following positions.  The positions as specified in this section are not to be
involved in any field building inspection.  These positions are of a clerical
nature and not under civil service.
   (a)   Inspector III, who shall not be under civil service (unclassified) and
shall have a general knowledge of the building trades but need not be certified
by the State.  He shall perform the duties of counter clerk within the Division
and shall perform such further duties as directed by the Chief Building
Official.
   (b)   Inspector III, who shall not be under civil service (unclassified) and
need not be certified by the State.  He shall handle zoning matters and
miscellaneous complaints received by the Division in addition to such other
duties as may be directed by the Chief.
      (Ord. 1976-98.  Passed 6-22-76.)
135.05  TEMPORARY INSPECTORS.
   The position of Temporary Inspectors I, II and III in the Division of
Inspections is hereby established.  The positions of Temporary Inspectors I, II
and III shall not be under civil service (unclassified) and shall be filled by
appointment by the Director of Public Safety.  The duties of Temporary
Inspectors I, II and III shall be to perform the identical duties of Inspectors
I, II and III at any time that Inspectors I, II and III may be absent for any
reason from their duties.
(Ord. 1976-98.  Passed 6-22-76.)
135.06  OTHER EMPLOYEES.
   Any other employee of the Division of Inspection who has not been mentioned
under this chapter is not under civil service.
(Ord. 1976-98.  Passed 6-22-76.)
135.07  CLARIFICATION OF ORDINANCES.
   Any reference to the Division of Building, Engineering and Inspection under
the former title is to be considered as the Division of Inspection under any
section of the ordinances of the City.  Any reference to Building
Administrator, Chief of the Division of Inspection, or Chief Building
Administrator in any section of the ordinances of the City is hereby meant to
be the Chief Building Official.
(Ord. 1992-064.  Passed 3-10-92.)

141.01  RECREATION DIRECTOR:  POSITION ESTABLISHED; DUTIES; RULES.
   (a)   There is hereby established the office of Director of Recreation for
the City.  The Director of Recreation shall be appointed by the Mayor and such
appointment shall be confirmed by a majority vote of the members elected to
Council.  The Director of Recreation shall serve for a term of two years,
effective January 1, 1972.  The compensation for the Director of Recreation
shall be at the rate provided in Chapter
155.
   (b)   The Director shall annually submit to Council, with copies to the
Mayor and Director of Finance, a recreation program for the current year and
shall administer such portion of the recreation program as is possible in
accordance with such funds as may be provided through appropriation by Council,
including the conduct, supervision and operation of public playgrounds,
playfields, recreation centers, swimming pools and other recreation areas and
facilities controlled by the City, and shall promulgate and enforce all rules
and regulations for the conduct of park and recreational facilities of the
City.  The Director of Recreation may be removed by the Mayor at any time with
the consent of five members of Council.
(Ord. 1972-1.  Passed 1-11-72.)
   (c)   The Director of Recreation is hereby authorized and empowered to make
and establish rules and regulations for the control, management and operation
of Recreation Department buildings and facilities.  Such rules and regulations
shall be deemed to be in full force and effect after five days' posting in the
five public places designated by Council for the posting of ordinances as
specified in Section
113.01.
(Ord. 1970-23.  Passed 2-24-70.)
   (d)   The Director of Recreation is hereby authorized and empowered to make
and establish fees for City-sponsored programs and activities, in the amount to
cover costs for that particular program, and such fees shall not exceed twenty-
five dollars ($25.00) per participant and/or material. 
(Ord. 1982-039.  Passed 3-23-82.)
141.02  EASTLAKE RECREATION ADVISORY COMMITTEE.
   (a)   A Eastlake Recreation Advisory Committee is hereby created consisting
of the following members:
   A representative of Eastlake Police Athletic/Activities League,
   A representative of the Eastlake Baseball League,
   A representative of Eastlake Youth Football,
   A representative of Eastlake Boys' Softball,
   A representative of Eastlake Girls' Softball,
   A representative of Eastlake Youth Basketball,
   A representative of Eastlake Gymnastics Association,
   A representative of Eastlake Soccer Association, Inc.,
   A representative of the Eastlake Swim Team,
   A representative of the Senior Citizens Advisory Board,
   A representative of The Western Lake County Chamber of Commerce.
   (b)   The Recreation Director and the Chairman of Council's Recreation
Committee shall be consultants to the Eastlake Recreation Advisory Committee.
   (c)   The Eastlake Advisory Committee shall discuss and make recommendations
concerning planning and development of recreation facilities, submit ideas for
recreation activities within the City and generally assist in creating a better
line of communication between the City and its citizenry concerning recreation
programs.
   (d)   The Eastlake Advisory Committee is authorized to pass by-laws, but
these by-laws shall not become effective until final approval of the same by
Council. Upon approval by Council, a copy of such by-laws shall be kept by the
Eastlake Advisory Committee and the Clerk of Council. 
(Ord. 2009-076.  Passed 7-14-09.)
141.03  SENIOR CITIZENS COORDINATOR.
   There is hereby established in the City the position of Senior Citizens
Coordinator.  The duties of the Senior Citizens Coordinator shall be to provide
a comprehensive recreation schedule for older adults through a diversity of
programs that will promote the creative use of leisure time; to promote
understanding of problems of the aged to the community.  The Senior Citizens
Coordinator shall perform all other duties as placed upon the Coordinator by
the Recreation Director.
(Ord. 1978-027.  Passed 2-16-78.)
CHAPTER 142
Parks Maintenance and Development Coordinator
142.01   Duties; qualifications.
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to establish - see CHTR. Art.
VI, Sec.
1
Parks and public lands - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
539
Park and recreation facilities - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.

142.01  DUTIES; QUALIFICATIONS.
   (a)   There is hereby established the position of Parks Maintenance and
Development Coordinator of the City.  The duties of the Parks Maintenance and
Development Coordinator shall include:
      (1)   To develop the landscaping of all Municipal grounds and facilities.
      (2)   To supervise and coordinate landscape plantings and grounds
maintenance on public properties.
      (3)   To advise Council and the various City departments on landscaping
projects on public properties.
      (4)   To assist in the development of public parks and properties.
      (5)   To assist in the maintenance of shade trees along the City rights
of way.
   (b)   The Parks Maintenance and Development Coordinator shall be a qualified
landscaper with a minimum of ten years experience.
   (c)   The Parks Maintenance and Development Coordinator shall be compensated
at the rate of two hundred twenty dollars ($220.00) biweekly.
   (d)   The chairman or a member of the Park and Shade Tree Commission, or a
chairman or member of any other board or commission, may also be designated as
the Parks Maintenance and Development Coordinator.
(Ord. 1995-088.  Passed 4-11-95.)
