143.01  ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERS; TERMS.
   The Eastlake Park and Shade Tree Commission is hereby established.  It shall
consist of five resident members who hold no other public office; they shall be
appointed by the Mayor, subject to the confirmation of two-thirds of all the
members elected to Council.  The terms of the first appointed members shall be
of such length and so arranged that the term of one member will expire each
year, and the members thereafter will be appointed and shall hold office for
terms of five years.  Any vacancy occurring other than by expiration of term
shall be filled for the unexpired portion of the term in the same manner as
provided for original appointment.
(Ord. 1956-39.  Passed 3-20-56.)
143.02  POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Park and Shade Tree Commission, within the budget appropriation approved
by Council, shall have the power and duty:
   (a)   To frame a master plan for providing adequate park, playground and
recreation areas for the convenience, comfort and pleasure of the inhabitants
of the City.
   (b)   To make recommendations to Council and the Planning Commission for the
location, character and extent of park, playground and recreation areas.
   (c)   To formulate and recommend to Council a master shade tree program for
the City.
   (d)   To conduct a continuing search for suitable park, playground and
recreation areas and to have appraisals made of the value of such locations and
facilities located thereon.
   (e)   To cause preliminary plans and studies to be developed as to the most
suitable use to be made of all property acquired by the City for park,
playground or recreation uses.
   (f)   Upon authorization by Council, to negotiate for the acquisition of
property for park, playground and recreation purposes.
   (g)   Upon acquisition of property for park, playground or recreation
purposes, to prepare final plans for submission to Council of the recommended
development and use of such property.
      (Ord. 1962-142.  Passed 8-28-62.)
143.03  RULES; OFFICERS; MEETINGS.
   The Park and Shade Tree Commission may make its own rules and select its own
chairman and secretary by majority vote.  It shall keep a journal of its
proceedings and all of its meetings shall be open to the public.
(Ord. 1956-39.  Passed 3-20-56.)
143.04  COORDINATION WITH PLANNING COMMISSION.
   The Park and Shade Tree Commission shall at all times coordinate its
planning and activities with the Planning Commission, it being understood that
the powers and duties hereby established shall be in addition to and shall in
no way alter, change, restrict or amend powers and duties granted by Charter or
ordinance to the Planning Commission.
(Ord. 1956-39.  Passed 3-20-56.)
CHAPTER 144
Records Commission
144.01   Establishment; composition.
144.02   Duties.
CROSS REFERENCES

Attendance at meetings required - see ADM.

144.01  ESTABLISHMENT; COMPOSITION.
   Adhering to Ohio R.C. 149.39, there is hereby established a Records
Commission composed of the Mayor or his appointed representative, who shall act
as chairman, the Director of Finance, the Director of Law and a resident
appointed by the Mayor.  The Commission may appoint a Secretary who shall serve
at the pleasure of the Commission.  The Commission may employ an archivist to
serve under its direction.
(Ord. 1981-238.  Passed 11-24-81.)
144.02  DUTIES.
   The Commission shall meet at least once every six months, and upon call of
the chairman.
   The function of the Commission shall be to provide rules for retention and
disposal of records of the Municipal Corporation and to review applications for
one-time records disposal and schedules of records retention and disposition
submitted by municipal offices.  Records may be disposed of by the Commission
pursuant to the procedure outlined in this section.  The Commission may at any
time review any schedule it has previously approved, and for good cause shown
may revise that schedule.
   When Municipal records have been approved for disposal, a list of such
records shall be sent to the State Auditor.  If the Auditor disapproves of the
action by the Municipal Commission, in whole or in part, it shall so inform the
Commission within a period of sixty days and these records shall not be
destroyed.  Before public records are otherwise disposed of, the Ohio
Historical Society shall be informed and given the opportunity for a period of
sixty days to select for its custody or disposal such public records as it
considers to be of continuing historical value.
(Ord. 1981-238.  Passed 11-24-81.)

   A Port Authority is hereby created by Council under and by virtue of the
authority of Ohio R.C. 4582 and any amendments thereto.
(Ord. 1992-207.  Passed 11-24-92.)
145.02  JURISDICTION.
   The jurisdiction of the Port Authority shall include all of the territory
within the City.
(Ord. 1992-207.  Passed 11-24-92.)
145.03  MEMBERS; TERM.
   (a)   The Port Authority shall be governed by a Board of Directors
consisting of seven members, five to be appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by
Council and two to be appointed by Council and such members shall serve terms
as follows:
      (1)   Three members to serve terms of two years each.
      (2)   Four members to serve terms of four years each.
   (b)   Persons subsequently appointed to the Board to successive terms shall
serve for terms of four years, except those persons appointed to fill vacancies
who shall be appointed to only the unexpired term.  Any Director shall be
eligible for reappointment.  Each Director shall have been a qualified elector
of, or shall have had his business or place of employment in, one or more
political subdivisions within the area of the jurisdiction of the Port
Authority, for a period of at least three years next preceding his appointment.
(Ord. 1992-207.  Passed 11-24-92.)
145.04  POWERS AND AUTHORITY.
   The Port Authority shall have all of the powers and authority designated for
Port Authorities by the Ohio Revised Code.
(Ord. 1992-207.  Passed 11-24-92.)
145.05  CITY RESPONSIBILITY TO FURNISH MEETING ROOM.
   It shall be the responsibility of the City to furnish the Port Authority
with a place to hold their meetings, and give the Port Authority technical
assistance where possible.
(Ord. 1992-207.  Passed 11-24-92.)

155.01  GENERAL ADMINISTRATION.
   The following rates of pay and employment benefits contained in the
provisions set forth in this chapter are for the Department Directors and
Assistant Directors of the various City Departments, the Chief Building
Official, the Tax Administrator, the Clerk of Council/ Director of Legislative
Services, the Chief of Police and the Chief of the Fire Department, the Police
Lieutenant who was exempted from the FOP labor contract, the Mayor's Secretary
and any other full time, and  part-time employees  not covered under the terms
of a Collective Bargaining Agreement.
   (a)   Definitions.  It is the intent of the City of Eastlake to clarify the
definitions of employment classifications so that employees understand their
employment status and benefit eligibility.  These classifications do not
guarantee employment for any specified period of time.  Accordingly, the right
to terminate the employment relationship at will at any time is retained by
both the employee and City of Eastlake.  These employees and individuals who
are covered by the State Constitution, Charter of the City of Eastlake and are
elected officials are excluded from the "at will" terminology.
      (1)   "Elected Official" means the Mayor and members of Council of the
City of Eastlake.
      (2)   "Employee" means any person working for the City for salary or
wages, who is not an "elected official" as defined herein.
      (3)   “Regular Full-Time Employees” means those who are not in a
temporary or probationary status and who are regularly scheduled to work City
of Eastlake's full-time schedule of at least forty (40) hours per week, or
firemen who work a full-time work schedule.  Generally, they are eligible for
City of Eastlake's benefit package, subject to the terms, conditions and
limitations of each benefit program.
      (4)   “Regular Part-time Employees” means those who are not assigned to a
temporary or probationary status and who are scheduled to work less than forty
(40) hours per week.  While they do receive all legally mandated benefits (such
as workers' compensation insurance and PERS), they are ineligible for some of
City of Eastlake's other benefit programs.
      (5)   “Probationary Employees” means those whose performance is being
evaluated to determine whether further employment in a specific position or
with City of Eastlake is appropriate.  Employees who satisfactorily complete
the probationary period shall be notified of their new employment
classification.  Probationary employees do receive all legally mandated
benefits such as workers' compensation  insurance and PERS.
      (6)   “Temporary and Seasonal Employees” means are those who are hired as
interim replacements, to temporarily supplement the work force, or to assist in
the completion of a specific project.  Employment assignments in this category
are of a limited duration.  Employment beyond any initially stated period does
not in any way imply a change in employment status.  Temporary and Seasonal
employees retain that status unless and until notified of a change.  While
temporary and seasonal employees receive all legally mandated benefits (such as
workers' compensation insurance and PERS), they are ineligible for some of City
of Eastlake's other benefit programs such as vacation and sick leave.
      (7)   “Casual Employees” means those who have established an employment
relationship with the City of Eastlake but who are assigned to work on an
intermittent and/or unpredictable basis.  While they receive all legally
mandated benefits (such as workers' compensation insurance and PERS), they are
ineligible  for some of City of Eastlake's other benefit programs. 
(Ord. 2010-099.  Passed 10-12-10.)
   (b)   Full-Time Employees Not Covered by a Union Agreement - Annual wages
based on a twenty-six (26) pay year Unless Specified Otherwise.  In years with
a twenty-seventh (27th) pay, the (27th) pay is added to the annual wages.

155.02  VACATION PAY.
   (a)   Each full time City employee not covered by a collective bargaining
agreement shall be entitled to vacation with pay as follows:
 
                  Vacation
One to four years Two weeks
Five years        Three weeks
Ten years         Four weeks
Fifteen years     Five weeks
Twenty years      Six weeks
 
   Employees shall become eligible for vacation leave after their probationary
period ends, earned pro-rata on their time of employment.  Vacation leave shall
normally be taken by the employee within twelve months thereafter.  Employees
shall be permitted to carry over from one year to the next immediate year, up
to two years of earned but unused vacation leave.
   In case of emergency, the department head has the right to require employees
to work on all or part of planned vacation leave. If an employee is required to
work under the circumstances set forth above, the employee shall be paid an
amount equal to one and one half times the usual compensation for the day or
days so worked and the employee shall have the vacation days worked scheduled
for a later time in the calendar year.
   Employees with at least one year of continuous service with the City, upon
separation from employment with the City, except for cause, will be entitled to
all unused vacation leave to his credit at the time of separation and a credit
of the pro-rata vacation leave earned from the employee's last anniversary
date. Said pro-rata calculation to be determined by calculating the number of
days between the employee's last anniversary date and the date of separation,
dividing that amount by 365 and then multiplying the answer by the number of
hours of vacation the employee would have had credited at his/her next
anniversary date. All vacation hours will be paid at the employee's current
rate of pay. The death of an employee shall result in this amount being paid to
the employee's estate.
   (b)   For the purposes of definition, a "regular part-time employee" must
work for the City for at least fifty-two consecutive weeks, at least ten hours
per week but not more than twenty -four hours per week.  "Temporary/seasonal
employees" who are retained for specific periods, without limitations, are not
to be confused with regular part-time employees.
   (c)   All regular part-time employees will accumulate credit toward vacation
leave prorated by the number of hours worked during each continuous and
complete year(s) of aforementioned service.  Basis for prorates will be 2,080
full-time hours for all departments and will be credited if or after said
employee completes probation.  Duly sworn members of the Division of Fire or
Fire Safety are specifically excluded from this section due to the fact that
calculations had been made when the Department went from part-time to full-time
in 1981 and the Court upheld those calculations.
   (d)   Absence, on account of sickness, injury or disability, in excess of
that authorized for such purpose may, at the request of the employee and within
the discretion of the department head, be charged against such employee's
vacation leave.
   (e)   If an employee has used a minimum of three weeks from their previous
year's vacation award, they may, with two weeks' notice, receive payment at
their regular rate for any unused hours.
   (f)   With notice, during the three (3) years preceding requested
retirement, the Chief of Police and Chief of Fire may receive up to four (4)
weeks earned, but not used vacation pay. This payment will be included on or
about the anniversary date and shall be considered part of that year's annual
salary for pension purposes only.  Said benefits shall terminate on December
31, 2009. (Ord. 2018-004.  Passed 1-23-18.)
   (g)   The Mayor, as an elected official as defined in Section
155.01, shall receive six weeks’ vacation per year which vacation period shall
accrue immediately upon the first day of each year.  Two weeks of said six
weeks’ vacation period shall be carried over from one year to the next, with a
maximum carryover of six weeks.  There shall be no pay for any unused vacation
period upon conclusion of status of Mayor.  (Ord. 2018-076.  Passed 9-11-18.)
   (h)   In the hiring or retention of City personnel, the Mayor may award a
vacation of up to six weeks to the immediate credit of that individual. That
amount awarded shall then be the annual amount of vacation to be credited to
that employee on that employee’s anniversary date unless the employee is
entitled to more vacation under Section
155.02(a) herein. At the Mayor’s discretion, Directors, the Chief Building
Official, and the Economic Development Administrator may carry over additional
earned but unused vacation leave, or be paid for unused vacation without regard
to subsection (a) or (e).
(Ord. 2018-004.  Passed 1-23-18; Ord. 2019-018, passed 3-12-19.)
155.03  HOLIDAYS.
   (a)   The following days are hereby declared holidays for all full time, as
distinguished from part-time; permanent as distinguished from temporary
employees of the City, not covered by a collective bargaining agreement, except
that part-time police dispatchers shall be entitled to holiday pay when
scheduled to work:
   The first day of January, known as New Year's Day
   The third Monday in February, known as Presidents' Day
   Good Friday
   The last Monday in May, known as Decoration or Memorial Day
   The Fourth of July, known as Independence Day
   The first Monday in September, known as Labor Day
   The fourth Thursday in November, known as Thanksgiving
   The fourth Friday in November, the day after Thanksgiving
   Christmas Eve Day
   The twenty-fifty day of December, known as Christmas Day
   Four floating holidays.
   (Ord. 2014-045.  Passed 7-8-14.)
   (b)   When any holiday listed in subsection (a) hereof falls on a Sunday,
the following business day shall be considered the holiday.  When any such
holiday falls on a Saturday, the preceding business day shall be considered the
holiday.  In addition to the above holidays, any day may be designated as a
holiday by proclamation of the President of Council, upon the approval of a
majority of Council.
   (c)   City offices shall be closed on the holidays listed in subsection (a)
hereof and all full-time permanent employees of the City who have been employed
for a minimum of three months shall be compensated at their regular rate of
compensation, though not working on those holidays, except that directors need
not be employed for the minimum of three months before being so compensated. 
However, if in the opinion of a department head certain employees are required
to work on those holidays to provide for necessary services of the City, then
the department head shall designate those employees to work and they shall be
compensated for the holiday in addition to their regular rate of pay. 
(Ord.  1995-027.  Passed 1-24-95.)
   (d)   In the event an employee is absent from work on his last scheduled
work day before or the first scheduled work day after a designated holiday, the
employee shall not receive holiday compensation, unless approved by the Mayor
after the receipt of reasons and documentation of said reason for the absence. 
(Ord.  2000-151.  Passed 12-14-00.)
   (e)   At the discretion of the respective department head with consideration
of workloads and department needs, an employee not regularly scheduled may work
designated holidays.  The employee may then elect to take the additional
holiday compensation in the form of payment.  Employees shall have the pay
option for the years 2008, 2009 and 2010.
   An employee, who elects to take time off for the holidays, shall be required
to take the time off during the year in which it is accumulated and not be able
to carry over the time into the next year.
   Payments for holidays shall be made for the first pay of December each year
and prorated ahead for the Christmas holidays.  Any loss of time which would
affect these holidays will be adjusted accordingly. 
(Ord. 2009-058.  Passed 5-26-09.)
   (f)   The members of the Division of Fire working 2,704 hours scheduled per
year shall receive seven twenty-four hour tours of duty off with pay in lieu of
the twelve specified Citywide holidays. 
(Ord.  2000-151.  Passed 12-14-00.)
   Members of the Division of Fire who work a regular forty-hour week schedule,
shall take either straight time off with pay or be paid for the holidays at
their regular straight time rate of pay at the direction of the Chief.
   (g)   Any police lieutenant who works on a holiday as a regularly scheduled
shift and works overtime after completing his shift, shall receive two times
his regular hourly rate for all such extra hours on the overtime basis.
(Ord. 1995-027.  Passed 1-24-95.)
   (h)   (1)   Effective January 1, 2013, a Chief of Police who works on a
recognized holiday, or if his/her regular continuous schedule does not include
the day of the observed holiday, shall designate the days he/she wishes to take
off at a later date. Said days shall be subject to the advance approval of the
Safety Director as to when they may be taken.
      (2)   A Chief of Police electing to take time off for holidays, shall be
required to take the time during the year it is earned and not be able to carry
the time over into the next calendar year. Time not taken during the year shall
be paid in December of the year the holiday was earned.  Floating holidays must
be taken during the year and cannot be paid out.
(Ord. 2014-001. Passed 1-28-14.)
155.04  OVERTIME.
   (a)   All non-safety forces full time employees will be entitled to receive
pay at the rate of one and one-half times their regular hourly rate for all
hours actually worked in excess of eight hours in any day, or forty hours in a
week.
   (b)   Fire Department Battalion Chiefs.  Employee(s) assigned work in excess
of their normal work schedule shall be paid one and one-half times their
regular hourly rate or one and one-half time compensatory time, at the
employee's election.  The normal work schedule shall be not more than eight (8)
tours of duty in a twenty-six (26) day period, except for forty hour employees.
   In the event an employee is called in to work after he has left work or on a
day when he is not scheduled to work, the employee will be guaranteed a minimum
of two hours pay at his straight time rate of pay or one and one-half times his
regular hourly rate for all hours actually worked, whichever is greater,
providing such hours do not abut the employees normally scheduled workday.
   Employees shall be able to elect payment in either cash or compensatory time
earned under this section and shall be able to accrue compensatory time up to a
maximum of 159.  Such time shall only be used with the advance approval of the
Chief so no overtime payment is needed.
   Employees with earned but unused compensatory time in their compensatory
bank may be able to cash in the compensatory time up to a maximum of fifty-
three hours pay once per year upon one week advance notice to the Finance
Department, when such employee requires the cash.
   (c)   Police Lieutenants.  All employees when performing assigned overtime
work will be entitled to receive pay at their FLSA overtime rate of one and
one-half time compensatory time for all hours worked in excess of the employees
normally scheduled workday or all hours worked in excess of the employee's
normally scheduled workweek.  There shall be no pyramiding of overtime
payments.  This rate shall exclude all work specified or similar to the work
described in the following paragraph:
   Employees who are required to appear in court shall receive a two hour
minimum in compensatory time, or one and one-half times the time actually spent
in court and such time shall be either paid or compensatory time as requested
by the employee.  Roll call, training, departmental meetings and other
administrative functions, shall receive straight time compensatory time for
such time as required.
   Compensatory time may be accumulated to a maximum of 120 hours to be taken
off at a future date, providing that the use of compensatory time is approved
of in advance by the employee's supervisor and does not require the utilization
of another employee on an overtime basis to work for the employee on
compensatory time.  The use of compensatory time shall not be denied for the
sole purpose of imposing discipline.
   Employees shall have the option of accumulating such compensatory time or
once per year, turning such time in for cash payment at the employee's straight
time hourly rate up to a maximum of forty hours cash payment upon one week
advance notice to the Finance Department, when such employee requires the cash
because of unforeseen emergency or vacation, etc.  Compensatory time earned
above the 120 hour limit shall be paid for in cash payments.  Any requests for
payments in excess of once per year shall be at the sole discretion of the
employer.
(Ord. 1991-247.  Passed 12-30-91.)
   (d)   The Mayor and Council, as elected officials as defined in Section
155.01(a) shall not receive overtime or compensatory time. 
(Ord. 2004-069.  Passed 7-13-04.)
155.05  SICK LEAVE.
   (a)   Sick leave shall be defined as an absence with pay necessitated by the
illness or injury of the employee or serious injury or death in the employee's
immediate family.
(Ord. 1991-248.  Passed 12-30-91.)
   (b)   All employees shall earn sick leave at the rate of four and six tenths
hours for every eighty hours worked, excluding overtime, and may accumulate
such sick leave up to an unlimited amount.
   The Mayor, as an elected official as defined in Section
155.01(a), shall not earn sick leave, and has no obligation to account for his
sick leave as he is salaried.
(Ord. 2004-058.  Passed 6-8-04.)
   (c)   All Fire Department employees working a 104 hour biweekly schedule
shall earn sick leave at the rate of six hours for every 104 hours worked,
excluding overtime, up to an unlimited amount. 
(Ord.  2000-152.  Passed 12-14-00.)
   (d)   An employee who is to be absent on sick leave shall notify his
supervisor of such absence and the reason therefor at least one-half hour
before the start of his work shift each day he is absent, unless the absence is
expected to be for more than three days or one tour of duty for the Fire
Division employees, where the employee will then give the employer an
approximate date of his return to work.
   (e)   An employee absent for more than three consecutive work days or one
tour of duty for Fire Division employees, shall supply a physician's report to
be eligible for paid sick leave, unless such report is waived by the department
head.
   (f)   If an employee fails to submit adequate proof of illness or injury
upon request, or in the event that upon such proof as is submitted or upon the
report of a medical examination, the department head finds there is not
satisfactory evidence of illness sufficient to justify the employee's absence
such leave may be considered an unauthorized leave and shall be without pay.
   (g)   Any abuse of sick leave, e.g. for purposes other than due to illness
or injury, in conjunction with days off on a regular basis, etc., shall be
sufficient cause for discipline as may be determined by the employer.
   (h)   All employees shall be notified in writing each year of the amount of
accumulated sick leave possessed by such employee.
   (i)   A ninety day provisional appointee and/or a permanent part-time
employee shall be entitled to sick leave prorata for the time actually worked
at the same rate as that granted to full time employees.  As used in this
section, a permanent part-time employee shall have a definite and certain
hourly work schedule and not be subject to emergency calls and/or the employee
shall not be entitled to sick leave benefits from any other employer.
(Ord. 1991-248.  Passed 12-30-91.)
155.06  SICK LEAVE TO BE CUMULATIVE; RETIREMENT PROVISION.
   (a)   Retirement, as used in this section, as defined by Ohio R.C. 124.39,
means disability or service retirement under any state retirement system in
this State.
      (1)   Employees starting employment on or after January 1, 2012.  Upon
said disability or service retirement or death of a full-time employee who has
completed not less than ten years of continuous service with the City, such
employee shall be entitled to receive cash payment equal to the employee's
hourly rate of pay in accordance with the following schedule:
 
 
Length of Service (Years) Percentage of 960 hours
over 10                   25%
 
Payment will be made on hours accumulated while under the employment of the
City of Eastlake.
(Ord. 2012-004.  Passed 2-14-12.)
      (2)   Employees employed prior to January 1, 2012.  Upon said disability
or service retirement or death of a full-time employee who has completed not
less than ten years of municipal service with the employer, such employee shall
be entitled to receive cash payment equal to the employee's hourly rate of pay
in accordance with the following schedule:
 
Length of Service (Years) Percentage of 1344 hours
10 to 12                  25% plus 20% of hours over 1344
Over 12                   50% plus 20% of hours over 1344
 
Payment will be made on hours accumulated while under the employment of the
City of Eastlake.
         (Ord. 2013-079.  Passed 11-26-13.)
   (b)   The cumulative retirement provided in paragraph (a) shall be paid to
the employee at a rate of the greater of 40% of the total retirement payout or
ten thousand dollars ($10,000) and paid at the time of retirement; the greater
of 30% of the remaining retirement payout or ten thousand dollars ($10,000) and
paid on the 1st day of the first subsequent budgetary calendar of the City of
Eastlake; and the remaining payout paid on the 1st day of the second subsequent
budgetary calendar of the City of Eastlake.  Upon written notification of the
employee’s intent to retire made forty-five days prior to the 1st day of the
budgetary calendar, the cumulative retirement provided in paragraph (a) shall
be paid to the employee at a rate of the greater of 60% of the total retirement
payout or ten thousand dollars ($10,000) and paid at the time of retirement;
and the remaining payout paid on the 1st day fo the first subsequent budgetary
calendar of the City of Eastlake.
   Payouts of less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000) shall be paid in a lump
sum payment.
   (c)   In the event of death, the employee’s estate shall be entitled to a
lump sum payment. 
   (d)   In the event of a catastrophic, terminal illness of an employee, the
employee shall be entitled to a lump sum payment upon retirement or
resignation.  The employee shall file an application with the Administration
setting forth the emergency and authorization for a lump sum payment of
benefits shall be awarded upon review and approval of the Administration.
   (e)   The Mayor shall not receive a cash payment equal to his hourly rate of
pay accumulated at the time of his retirement, resignation or death.
(Ord. 2004-120.  Passed 10-26-04.)
155.07  USE OF SICK LEAVE.
   When the use of sick leave is due to an illness in the immediate family,
"immediate family" includes only the employee's parents, spouse, child or any
other relative residing with the employee.  When the use of sick leave is due
to death in the immediate family, "immediate family" includes only the
employee's parents, spouse, child, brother, sister, mother-in-law, father-in-
law, sister-in-law, brother-in-law, grandparents, grandchildren, half-brother,
half-sister or other person residing with the employee at the time of death.
(Ord. 1998-017. Passed 1-27-98.)
155.08  SICK LEAVE FOR PART OF A DAY.
   Sick leave may be used in segments of not less than four hours, or six hours
for Fire Division employees, except in the case of doctor and dental
appointments and a hospital visit to the immediate family, where the employee
may use sick leave in one hour segments, providing the employee gives the
employer notice of such appointment at the beginning of his work shift.
(Ord. 1987-051.  Passed 3-24-87.)
155.09  PHYSICIAN'S CERTIFICATE FOR SICK LEAVE.
   Upon the expected return to work of any employee from an absence due to
personal illness or injury and an issue is raised as to the employee's fitness
to perform the required work, prior to and as a condition of his return to
work, the employer may require the employee to be examined, by a physician
designated and paid by the employer, to establish that he is not disabled from
the performance of his normal duties and that his return to work will not
jeopardize the health and safety of other employees.
(Ord. 1987-051.  Passed 3-24-87.)
155.10  INJURY LEAVE.
   (a)   When an employee has a service connected illness or injury while
actually working for the employer, he shall be eligible for a paid leave not to
exceed thirty working days from injury date, providing he files for Workers’
Compensation and signs a waiver assigning to the employer those sums of money
he would ordinarily receive as his weekly compensation as determined by law for
those number of weeks he receives benefits under this section.  The employee
shall then utilize his sick leave, vacation, etc.  until he returns to full
duty.  Sick leave, etc.  will be fully reimbursed, if any Workers’ Compensation
is received for such days, by the employer.  All injuries must be reported on
the shift of occurrence, or within one calendar week, to be eligible for
payments under this section.
(Ord.  2000-154.  Passed 12-14-00.)
   (b)   Before any payment is made pursuant to the provisions in subsection
(a) hereof, the applicant shall furnish and periodically thereafter provide
satisfactory proof of the amount received by him, under Workers' Compensation
Law, to the Director of Finance.
   (c)   Should any employee be entitled to disability benefits from the Police
and Firemen's Disability and Pension Fund, such disability payments shall
continue only until such time as the employee is eligible to be placed on
disability pension as provided by the rules and regulations governing
disability benefits arising from injuries sustained while in the course of
employment. 
(Ord. 1987-051.  Passed 3-24-87.)
155.11  MILITARY LEAVE.
   In accordance with State law, any employee, who presents official orders
requiring his attendance for a period of training or active duty as a member of
the United States Armed Forces, shall be entitled to military leave without
reduction in total income for a period or periods not exceeding a total of
thirty-one calendar days in any one year.  Such military leave shall be in
addition to and may not be concurrent with authorized vacation leave.  Any
employee who enters extended military service with the armed forces shall be
granted a leave of absence without pay to extend until ninety days beyond the
termination of such service.
(Ord. 1987-051.  Passed 3-24-87.)
155.12  SPECIAL LEAVE.
   (a)   In addition to other authorized leaves, a department head may
authorize an employee to be absent without pay for personal reasons for a
period or periods not to exceed ten working days in any calendar year.
   (b)   The Mayor, with the approval of Council, may authorize special leaves
of absence with or without pay for any period or periods not to exceed three
calendar months in any one calendar year, for the following purposes: 
attendance at a college, university or business school for the purpose of
training in subjects related to the work of the employee and which will benefit
the employee and the City service; urgent personal business requiring the
employee's attention for an extended period, such as settling estates,
liquidating a business, serving on a jury and attending court as a witness; and
for other purposes that are deemed beneficial to the City service.
   (c)   Council upon the recommendation of a department head, may grant leaves
of absence, with or without pay, in excess of the limitations herein, for the
purpose of attending extended courses of training at a recognized university or
college and for other purposes that are deemed beneficial to the City service.
(Ord. 1987-051.  Passed 3-24-87.)
155.13  ABSENCE WITHOUT LEAVE.
   An employee who is absent from duty shall report the reason to his
supervisor prior to the date of absence when possible and in no case later than
noon on the first day of absence.  All unauthorized and unreported absences
shall be considered absences without leave, and deduction of pay shall be made
for the period of absence.  Such absence may be made the grounds for
disciplinary action.  An employee who is absent for more than three working
days without notifying his supervisor shall have his employment terminated.
(Ord. 1987-051.  Passed 3-24-87.)
155.14  FUNERAL LEAVE.
   (a)   A full time employee shall be granted time off with pay for the
purpose of attending the funeral, upon death of a member of the employee's
immediate family.  The employee shall be entitled to a maximum of three working
days for each death in his immediate family.  For the purpose of this section
"immediate family" includes only the employee's spouse, children, parents,
sister, brother, grandparents, grandchildren, mother-in-law, father-in-law, and
step family or any other relative living with employee at the time of death.
   If an employee requires more time than contained in the above paragraph, he
may utilize vacation time, sick leave or leave without pay, with the approval
of the employee's department head.
   (b)   Members of the Fire Division working 2,704 hours scheduled per year
should be entitled to one shift off as applied to the above.
(Ord. 1997-183.  Passed 12-30-97.)
155.15  CLERK OF COUNCIL.(REPEALED)
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
155.15 was repealed by Ordinance 2009-034, passed April 28, 2009.
155.16  DIRECTOR OF LAW.
   (a)   The Director of Law shall be paid as indicated in Section
155.01 for legal services in attending regular and special meetings of Council;
attendance at meetings of Municipal boards and commissions when requested by
the Mayor; furnishing of legal counsel and opinions to all officers, boards and
commissions of the City in connection with Municipal affairs; and performing
all legal services required by the City
   (b)   For all other services performed or furnished by the Director of Law,
in addition to those services required in subsection (a) hereof, he shall be
paid compensation in an amount equal to the specified rate of thirty-five
dollars ($35.00) per hour as approved by the Mayor and Council.
   (c)   The Law Director shall present to the Clerk of Council a written
opinion on any matter affecting the official business of the City when a
written opinion or report has been requested by Council.  In any litigation
where the City is a defendant, the Director shall take all steps which in his
discretion, are warranted for the protection of the City, but the Law Director
shall advise Council as to all litigation in which the City is a party, and
upon request of Council, shall report the status of any pending case or cases;
and, upon request of Council, shall estimate for the benefit of Council the
cost of the suit.
   (d)   When the Law Director is required to travel out of town on City
business he shall be reimbursed for travel expense as outlined in Section
155.18.
(Ord. 2009-035.  Passed 4-28-09.)
155.17  TERMINATION PAY CONDITIONED UPON RETURN OF CITY PROPERTY.
   (a)   Upon the voluntary or involuntary termination of employment of any
City employee for any reasons, each such City employee shall return to his
department director, or to his immediate supervisor, all City property
including, but not limited to, his official City ID card, keys related to City
property, tools and equipment issued by and/or belonging to the City and all
other property items related to his City employment.
   (b)   The Director of Finance is hereby ordered to withhold final payment to
any such terminated City employee, including regular or overtime compensation,
accrued sick leave and/or vacation benefits, etc., pending such employee's full
compliance with subsection (a) hereof.
(Ord. 1987-051.  Passed 3-24-87.)
155.18  TRAVEL EXPENSE.
   (a)   There are occasions when attendance at conferences, conventions,
meetings, schools, training programs, etc. by employees and elected
representatives of the City is in the best interest of the City.  Therefore,
the following procedures are adopted and shall be adhered to relative to travel
expenses. 
(Ord. 1992-058.  Passed 12-14-00.)
   (b)   All administrative departmental expenses shall be approved in advance
by the Mayor by using the “Travel Expense Authorization” form (form TE-I).  A
program of the meeting/conference shall be attached to form TE-I prior to
receiving approval.
   All legislative departmental expenses shall be approved in advance by the
President of Council by using the “Travel Expense Authorization” form (form TE-
I).
   A program of the meeting/conference shall be attached to form TE-I prior to
receiving approval.
   A separate form is to be completed for each employee that is attending the
meeting/conference, projecting the estimated cost using the following
parameters:
      (1)   Air travel shall be by coach class unless there is no alternative
and then the indication shall be shown on the TE-I form of that fact. 
Employees shall be paid at the rate established by the Federal Government, or
the round trip air fare, whichever is lesser when using their own car.
      (2)   Lodging expense.  Only hotel, motel or bed and breakfast inn
expenses shall be allowed.  The maximum expense, per employee per day, shall
not exceed the per diem allowance rates in effect per Internal Revenue Service
Code or publications.  Lodging expenses, when requested, can be shared by more
than one employee.  The only exception to this limit is when the employee or
official is staying at the same hotel or lodging facility where the conference
or seminar is being held.
      (3)   Registration fees.  Registration fees, including meals and other
programmed affairs sponsored by the conference or convention organization shall
be reimbursed upon presentation of receipts by the employee.  When the pre-
registration is required, the fee may be charged to the City, proving that
approval for the trip has been obtained.
      (4)   Meal allowance. Meal allowance may be authorized, not to exceed the
per diem allowance rates in effect per Internal Revenue Service Code or
publication.  The federal standard meal allowance shall be allocated based on
the Internal Revenue Service Code or publication.  Receipts for meal allowance
are not required.  The per diem rate includes all meals and tips, taxes and
gratuities for meals.
      (5)   Miscellaneous expenses.  Miscellaneous expenses such as, books or
supplies for use at the conference or seminar, taxi fares, public
transportation, car rental, parking fees and gratuities (not to exceed 15%),
may be claimed if circumstances indicate that they are necessary for the
traveler.  Reimbursement shall not be made for personal items such as long
distance telephone calls, valet service, laundry, toiletries, room mini bars,
pay cable movies or alcoholic beverages.
      (6)   Statement and evidence of travel expense.  Within ten working days
after the return of the employee, the travel expense shall be itemized on the
travel expense form (Form TE-I) under the column listed as “actual” expenses. 
This report shall be completed using the criteria described in this chapter. 
Where more than one employee was attending the meeting/conference, each
employee shall complete Form TE-I.
      (7)   Local expense.  Local expenses required for the furtherance of
official City business by department heads and division heads are authorized,
excluding the purchase of alcoholic beverages, for themselves and guests in
local restaurants and meeting facilities.  Such expenses shall be submitted
with evidence describing the participants attending and reasons for the
expenses incurred.
      (8)   Travel advance.  Travel advances may be granted upon approval of
Form TE-I.  When submitting Form TE-I, if any funds are to be returned to the
City or if money is due to the employee, all information shall be recorded in
the proper columns.
      (9)   Personal benefits.  No personal benefits such as frequent flyer
miles, rewards, prizes and the like shall be procured by a city official/
employee when traveling at the city’s expense.  (Ord. 2018-086.  Passed 11-13-
18.)
155.19  AUTHORIZATION TO EXPEND GOVERNMENTAL FUNDS.
   (a)   Council hereby authorizes the expenditure of Municipal funds during
major emergency situations to be used for the purpose of providing food for
residents and employees assisting in an emergency.  Authorization for these
expenditures shall be approved by the Mayor.
   (b)   Council and the Mayor may authorize the expenditure of governmental
funds to be used for the purpose of food and beverages for multi-governmental
meetings or other civic events.  All expenditures shall be approved by the
Mayor and President of Council.
   (c)   The President of Council may authorize and approve the expenditure of
governmental funds for holding informational meetings for members of Council.
   (d)   The Director of Finance is authorized to expend funds for the purchase
of coffee, sugar and creamer, for the use by guests at City Hall, conferences
or meetings.
(Ord. 1994-202.  Passed 12-13-94.)
155.20  EMPLOYER PICKUP OF EMPLOYEE CONTRIBUTIONS TO OHIO PUBLIC EMPLOYEES
RETIREMENT SYSTEM (PERS); POLICE AND FIRE PENSION INCLUDED.  (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
155.20 was repealed by Ordinance 2011-162.)
155.21  UNIFORM ALLOWANCE.
   (a)   Police Officers and Fire Division Officers not covered by a collective
bargaining agreement shall be paid an annual uniform allowance in the same
amount paid to Police Officers and Fire Division who are covered by a
collective bargaining agreement.
(Ord. 2018-005.  Passed 1-23-18.)
   (b)   Special Police Officers shall be paid a uniform maintenance allowance
of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year, providing the Officer has completed
a minimum of 100 hours' service during the previous year.  Such amount shall be
paid on February 1 of each year.
(Ord. 2009-036.  Passed 4-28-09.)
155.22  LONGEVITY. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
155.22 was repealed by Ordinance 2018-006.)
155.23  EDUCATIONAL PAY FOR FULL-TIME FIRE AND POLICE PERSONNEL.
   (a)   Any full-time police personnel who has received a training certificate
attesting to the satisfactory completion of all law enforcement courses offered
towards an associate degree in law enforcement shall receive additional pay in
the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) per month.
   Any full-time fire personnel who has received a training certificate
attesting to the satisfactory completion of all courses offered towards an
associate degree in fire science technology or related field shall receive
additional pay in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) per month.
   (b)   Any full-time police personnel who has received an associate degree in
law enforcement shall receive additional pay in the amount of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) per month.
   Any full-time fire personnel who has received an associate degree in fire or
paramedic technology or related field shall receive additional pay in the
amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per month.
   (c)   Any full-time police personnel who has receive a bachelor’s degree in
law enforcement shall receive one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per month.
   Any full-time fire personnel who has receive a bachelor’s degree in fire or
paramedic technology or related field shall receive one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00) per month.
(Ord. 2002-063.  Passed 5-28-02.)
155.24  PART-TIME FIRE FIGHTERS.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE:  Former Section
155.24 was repealed by Ordinance 1992-144, Passed July 14, 1992.)
155.25  INCENTIVE PAY.
   Temporary Fill-In at Higher Level Excluding Safety Forces.  Any employee
selected to temporarily perform the duties of a higher classification in that
employee's absence, shall be paid sixty cents ($.60) or the existing hourly pay
rate for that position if less than sixty cents ($.60), more than his hourly
rate of pay during the performance of such duties.
(Ord. 1992-145.  Passed 7-14-92.)
155.26  BOND.
   (a)   The following officers and employees shall give bond securing faithful
performance in the amounts listed:
 
Director of Finance               $ 25,000.00
Assistant Director of Finance         25,000.00
Tax Coordinator/Administrator      25,000.00
Mayor                  10,000.00
 
   (b)   The following officers and employees shall give bond for theft and
dishonesty  as provided by the Northern Ohio Risk Management Association
(NORMA) in the amounts as listed:
 
Director of Finance             $ 500,000.00
Assistant Director of Finance         500,000.00
Tax Coordinator/Administrator      500,000.00
Mayor                  500,000.00
All other City officers and employees   500,000.00
 
   (c)   The officers and employees of the City other than the Director of
Finance, Deputy Director of Finance, Tax Coordinator/Administrator and Mayor
are to be covered by a single blanket for bond in the amounts provided in
subsection (a) hereof.
(Ord. 2010-018.  Passed 3-9-10.)
155.27  CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION.
   Each member of the Civil Service Commission, in the performance of his
regular duties as a member of the Commission shall have the option, at the
beginning of each year, of being paid fifty dollars ($50.00) per month, as a
travel and expense allowance; or be reimbursed for actual documented travel and
other expenses submitted to the Finance Department, not to exceed six hundred
dollars ($600.00) in a given year.
(Ord. 2013-47.  Passed 6-25-13.)
155.28  PLANNING COMMISSION, PARK AND SHADE TREE COMMISSION AND ZONING BOARD.
   Each member of the Zoning Board, Park and Shade Tree Commission and Planning
Commission in the performance of their regular duties shall have the option, at
the beginning of each year, of being paid fifty dollars ($50.00) per month, as
a travel and expense allowance; or be reimbursed for actual documented travel
and other expenses submitted to the Finance Department, not to exceed six
hundred dollars ($600.00) in a given year.
(Ord. 2013-48.  Passed 6-25-13.)
155.29  RETIREMENT AGE FOR SAFETY FORCES.
   Any full time frontline Police or Fire Division employee of the City who has
attained the age of seventy years shall, at such time, retire and have his
employment with the City terminated.
(Ord. 1987-051.  Passed 3-24-87.)
155.30  ADVANCEMENT OF BENEFITS FOR RETIREMENT.  (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
155.30 was repealed by Ordinance 2011-023.)
155.31  PERSONAL DAYS.
   (a)   The Chief of Police and all police lieutenants, in addition to all
other leave benefits, are hereby granted four personal days leave each year
which are to be taken within the year earned or forfeited.
   (b)   All Fire Division forty-hour employees, including the Chief, in
addition to all other leave benefits, are hereby granted four personal days
leave each year which are to be taken within the year earned or forfeited.
   (c)   All full-time employees, not included in any bargaining units, shall
earn one personal day in each calendar quarter (January to March, April to
June, July to September and October to December) that the employee uses no sick
leave. The personal days must be taken in the next immediate six-month period
or be forfeited.
   (d)   Personal days shall only be taken with the advance approval of the
Chief of the Division and when the work shift is at sufficient strength so the
employer will be not be required to have another employee work for the employee
requesting the day off.
(Ord. 2012-005.  Passed 2-14-12.)
155.32  TUITION AND FEES.
   All books, tuition and registration fees of courses taken by employees which
are related to their work shall be paid by the City provided that such books,
tuition and registration fees are approved of in advance by the Mayor in the
case of a member of the administration, and the Council President in the case
of a member of Council or Council staff, and the employee attains a passing
grade of "C" or better or obtains a certificate attesting to the passage of a
course where grades are not given.
(Ord. 1991-239.  Passed 12-10-91.)
155.33  PHYSICAL TRAINING FOR SAFETY PERSONNEL.
   The City and all non-union Safety Department personnel agree that a physical
conditioning program is needed and that such program will be administered
pursuant to the Physical Fitness Standard Provisions mutually agreed to
contained in the Department's Standard Operating Procedures (SOP).
   Effective June 1, 1991, all non-union Safety Department personnel shall be
required to fully participate in such program as a condition of employment.
(Ord. 1991-250.  Passed 12-30-91.)
155.34  MEDICAL EXAMINATIONS FOR SAFETY PERSONNEL.
   All non-union safety personnel shall be required to take an annual medical
examination (physical) to certify that he is in sufficiently good medical
health to perform his normal duties, as provided for in the Department Standard
Operating Procedures (SOP).  The physician shall be appointed and paid by the
City.  The employee and the City shall be provided with the results of the
examination on the form provided by the City.
(Ord. 1991-251.  Passed 12-30-91.)
155.35  PERSONNEL FILES.
   Employees shall be allowed to examine their personnel file upon submitting a
request to do so to the Human Resources Coordinator.  Such request shall be
submitted at least three work days in advance and shall be in writing.
   The time for reviewing the file shall be determined by the Human Resources
Coordinator, except that the time shall be during regular office hours.  The
Mayor and/or department head may be present during the review.
   Employees will be allowed to submit written explanations or rebuttals to any
inaccuracies of documents contained in the file, which written explanation
shall remain in the file.  Reprimands more than two years old may, at the
employee's request, be removed, providing that the employee has received no
other forms of discipline during such two-year period.
(Ord. 1995-031.  Passed 1-24-95.)
155.36  ALTERNATIVE WORK SCHEDULE.
   Individuals wishing to change their work schedule must fill out and submit,
to their department head, a request form stating the employee's desired work
schedule and the date the new schedule would begin.  The department head will
refer all requests, with appropriate recommended approval or disapproval, to
the Mayor for final decisions.  These decisions will be based on the following:
   (a)   All employees must be present between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 3:00
p.m.  However, starting times may be shifted forward or backward of the current
starting times in increments of one-half hour, up to a maximum shift of one
hour.
   (b)   Schedule changes must not conflict with other normal services.
   (c)   The requested work schedule must allow the employee to satisfy the
needs of the residents.  The needs of the City and individual departments must
be met first.
   (d)   The employee must be present during "exceptions" to normal work
schedule, including but not limited to time card submittals and special
meetings.
   (e)   The time span for which the requested work schedule change would apply
need not be stated, but a new request would be required for each change.  The
minimum time span for which change would apply would be two weeks.
Requests must be made at least two weeks before time span of alternative work. 
All decisions of the Mayor are final.
(Ord. 1995-032.  Passed 1-24-95.)
155.37  FAMILY MEDICAL LEAVE.
   Eligible employees must have been employees with the City for at least
twelve months and have 1,250 hours of service with the City during the twelve-
month period prior to any leave.  An eligible employee is entitled to take a
leave without pay for up to twelve weeks in any twelve-month period because of:
   (a)   The birth of a child of the employee and in order to care for the
child.  The eligibility for this leave expires twelve months after the birth of
the child.
   (b)   The placement of a child with the employee for adoption or foster
care.  The eligibility for this leave expires twelve months after the placement
of the child.
   (c)   The care for a child, spouse or parent of the employee who has a
serious health condition.
   (d)   A serious health condition that makes the employee unable to perform
the functions of the employee's position.
   While the leave is without pay, the City will pay health insurance benefits
in the same manner as if the employee were working during the twelve-week
period.
   Upon return from leave, the employee must be returned to the same or
equivalent position.
   An employee is required to use available paid vacation, sick leave or
personal leave to substitute for all or part of this twelve-week leave period. 
Under specified circumstances, this leave may be taken on an intermittent
basis.  Certification of need for leave may be required by the City. 
(Ord. 1995-033.  Passed 1-24-95.)
155.38  INSURANCES.
   (a)   The Employer shall provide health care insurance coverage for all
full-time employees, after the completion of the initial 60 days of employment
for all union employees, and the first of the month after hire for all section
155 employees.  The City will pay ninety percent (90%) of the cost of the
health care insurance; the employee shall pay the remaining ten percent (10%)
through automatic payroll deduction.  Employees will not be reimbursed by the
City for co-pays or deductibles with the exception that should the City
contract to provide healthcare coverage through a High Deductible Healthcare
Plan which includes a Health Savings Account obligation for the employee, the
City shall contribute to said employee’s Health Savings Account ninety percent
(90%) of the in network deductible obligation be it single, family or other.
(Ord. 2018-087.  Passed 11-13-18.)
   (b)   The Employer shall determine the level of benefits best meeting the
needs of the employer and shall be able to change insurance carriers or self-
insure.
   (c)   Any employee who obtains health care coverage through another source
may, with presentation of proof of such coverage, receive compensation as
follows:
      (1)   Two hundred dollars ($200.00) per month for employees eligible for
the family plan;
      (2)   One hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per month for employees
eligible for employee and spouse, or employee and children plan;
      (3)   One hundred dollars ($100.00) per month for employees eligible for
the single plan. 
   (d)   Payments will be made in the month following the month in which no
health care coverage was provided by the City.
   (e)   Council members shall not be entitled to receive health care insurance
through the  City of Eastlake. 
(Ord. 2016-062.  Passed 12-29-16.)
155.39  MILEAGE REIMBURSEMENT FOR USE OF PERSONAL VEHICLE.
   There are occasions when an employee must use their own vehicle for City
business.  If this situation should arise, due primarily to lack of an
available pool vehicle, the employee’s direct supervisor must authorize the use
of the personal vehicle in advance and the Mayor must subsequently approve it. 
Proof of insurance on the vehicle must be presented, with completion of the
appropriate form, for reimbursement at the same rate as permitted by state
regulations.
(Ord. 1997-037.  Passed 3-11-97.)
155.40  NEPOTISM PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS.
   (a)   No elected official, as defined in Section
155.01(a), shall exercise the influence or authority of the elected official’s
office so as to secure employment with the City for any member of the elected
official’s family.
   (b)   For purposes of subsection (a), “member of the elected official’s
family”, shall mean the elected official’s spouse, children, parents,
grandparents, grandchildren and siblings.
(Ord. 2005-026.  Passed 3-8-05.)
TITLE SEVEN - Judicial
Chap.
171.  Municipal Court.
CHAPTER 171
Municipal Court
   EDITOR'S NOTE:  The provisions of Ohio R.C. 1901.01 established the
Willoughby Municipal Court which, pursuant to Ohio R.C. 1901.02, has
territorial jurisdiction within the corporate limits of the municipalities of
Eastlake, Wickliffe, Willowick, Willoughby, Willoughby Hills, Kirtland,
Kirtland Hills, Waite Hill, Timberlake and Lakeline, and within Kirtland
Township, in Lake County.  The powers, duties and proceedings of the Court are
established by Ohio R.C. Chapter 1901.  Ohio R.C. 1901.25 provides that the
Municipal Court may provide by rule how jurors shall be chosen.  Jurors' fees
in any criminal case involving the violation of a City ordinance shall be paid
out of the City Treasury.  The Municipal Court, pursuant to Ohio R.C. 1901.26
(A), may establish a schedule of fees and costs to be taxed in any action or
proceeding, whether civil or criminal.  Ohio R.C. 1901.31(F) provides that
fines received for violation of Eastlake ordinances shall be paid into the City
Treasury.  Rule 18 of the Rules Governing Procedure in Traffic Cases as
promulgated by the Ohio Supreme Court provides that a court may establish a
Traffic Violations Bureau and specifies certain restrictions as to the
designated offenses and schedule of fines to be accepted as waiver payment in
lieu of court appearance.
CROSS REFERENCES
Release of Court Clerk's liability for loss of funds - see Ohio R.C. 131.18 et
seq.
Municipal court - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1901
Bond for Court Clerk required - see Ohio R.C. 1901.31(D)
Notification to Director of liquor law convictions - see Ohio R.C. 4301.991
Record of traffic violations - see Ohio R.C. 4513.37
