CHAPTER 711
Christmas Trees
711.01   License required; application.
711.02   Fees; license not transferable.
711.03   Restriction on sales.
711.04   Exception to license requirement.
711.05   Deposit required.
711.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Transporters of trees to carry bill of sale - see Ohio R.C. 4551.01
Transportation of trees by owner - see Ohio R.C. 4551.02
711.01  LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION.
   No person shall engage in the business of selling Christmas trees outdoors
within the corporate limits of the City except as provided in this chapter.
   Every vendor of Christmas trees shall obtain a license.  Application for the
license shall be made to the Chief Building Official, who shall issue the
license.
(Ord. 1961-315.  Passed 9-26-61.)
711.02  FEES; LICENSE NOT TRANSFERABLE.
   Fees for nontransferable licenses shall be collected as follows:
 
(a)      Persons established in the City in  the business of a nursery or tree $1.00
selling, on an annual basis, at a permanent location
(b)   Persons in any permanent business other than as designated in subsection (a)
hereof, and persons who have resided in the City for a period of one year, may     5.00
obtain a license at a fixed location for a period of three weeks
(c)   Itinerant persons or merchants at locations in the City which are temporar500.00
 
(Ord. 1961-315.  Passed 9-26-61.)
711.03  RESTRICTION ON SALES.
   No person shall conduct the business of selling Christmas trees in an area
or use district which is zoned for residential use.  No sale of Christmas trees
shall be made from a truck driven house-to-house.
(Ord. 1961-315.  Passed 9-26-61.)
711.04  EXCEPTION TO LICENSE REQUIREMENT.
   No license for the sale of Christmas trees is required of a church or
religious organization associated or connected with a church, bona fide
charitable, service or nonprofit or veterans' organization.  Such sales may be
conducted on the property of the church, bona fide charitable, service or
nonprofit or veterans' organization without a license.
(Ord. 1961-315.  Passed 9-26-61.)
711.05  DEPOSIT REQUIRED.
   In addition to the permit fee specified in Section
711.02, the permittee shall deposit with the Director of Finance the sum of
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to guarantee the removal of extra Christmas trees
and that the premises shall be cleared after the Christmas holiday has passed. 
Such deposit shall be returned upon the order of the Chief Building Official.
(Ord. 1961-315.  Passed 9-26-61.)
711.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the fourth degree.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day
during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 713
Coin-Operated Dry Cleaning Machines
713.01   Permits; plans; licensing.
713.02   Installation in nondwelling single-story buildings.
713.03   Type solvent; storage; handling.
713.04   General installation requirements.
713.05   Ventilation requirements.
713.06   Customer safety.
713.07   Machine design and maintenance.
713.99   Penalty.
713.01  PERMITS; PLANS; LICENSING.
   (a)   Plans shall be submitted to the Chief Building Official and a building
permit secured prior to installation of coin-operated dry cleaning equipment. 
Plans shall indicate the layout of all equipment and appurtenances.  Separate
permits shall be obtained for any electrical, plumbing and other work that may
be required.
   (b)   A license or a certificate of occupancy shall be issued upon final
approval by the Chief Building Official and the Fire Chief.  Such license or
certificate shall be renewed each year upon inspection by the above officers.
(Ord. 1961-394.  Passed  12-12-61.)
713.02  INSTALLATION IN NONDWELLING SINGLE-STORY BUILDINGS.
   All installation shall be confined to single-story buildings with concrete
floors.  No equipment shall be installed in buildings used in part as dwelling
units, nor shall any portion of a building be converted into a dwelling unit
after installation of equipment.
(Ord. 1961-394.  Passed 12-12-61.)
713.03  TYPE SOLVENT; STORAGE; HANDLING.
   (a)   Cleaning solvent used in coin-operated equipment must be of
nonflammable type.  Maximum allowable concentration (MAC) value must be 200 ppm
(parts per million).  The human tolerance (eight-hour day, no injurious
effects) shall be 200 ppm.
   (b)   Residue removed from the filters shall be stored in closed metal
containers outside of the main building.
   (c)   Storage of solvent in the customer area is prohibited.
      (Ord. 1961-394.  Passed 12-12-61.)
713.04  GENERAL INSTALLATION REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Dry cleaning machines and all equipment incidental to their operation
shall be housed in an enclosure excluding any and all other equipment.  No open
flame burning equipment is permitted within such enclosure.
   (b)   All machines and equipment shall be placed in a metal reservoir of
sufficient capacity to contain all the liquid "perc" contained in the machines,
filters and storage receptacles.  Means of draining the reservoir by gravity or
pump shall be provided.
   (c)   The enclosure shall be accessible to authorized personnel only. 
Public access to the machines shall be through the loading door only, which
door cannot be opened while the machine is in operation.
   (d)   Each dry cleaning machine shall be supplied with its own electrical
circuit.  All switches shall be located within the machine enclosure
inaccessible to the public.
   (e)   Machines shall be designed and electrically wired so as to make the
customer loading door unopenable in the event of power failure.
   (f)   All machines and equipment shall be grounded with a grounding
conductor, minimum size No. 10 copper wire, connected to a cold water pipe or
as required by the National Electrical Code.
(Ord. 1961-394.  Passed 12-12-61.)
713.05  VENTILATION REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Each machine shall be provided with an exhaust system.  A velocity of
100 feet per minute shall be maintained through the loading door when opened.
   (b)   A supply of make-up air, tempered sixty to sixty-five degrees
fahrenheit, equal to or greater than the volume exhausted shall be provided to
eliminate the possibility of negative pressure conditions.
   (c)   The interior of the machine and equipment enclosure shall have an
exhaust system to ventilate the area.  A minimum of 1,000 CFM per machine shall
be provided.
   (d)   All exhaust ducts shall be sealed by soldering or taping the joints
and shall discharge five feet above the roof.
   (e)   All exhaust stacks shall be located from any fresh air intake, window,
door or stairway a distance as determined by the Chief Building Official and
the Fire Chief.
(Ord. 1961-394.  Passed 12-12-61.)
713.06  CUSTOMER SAFETY.
   (a)   Instruction charts for the customer on the use of the machines shall
be conspicuously posted.
   (b)   A trained operator must be available or on call when the premises are
open for business.  A telephone with emergency numbers shall be installed.
   (c)   The following safety regulations, printed in large letters, shall be
posted in the customer area:
      (1)   Skin accidentally exposed to the "perc" solvent should be washed
with warm water and soap.  Apply lanolin, olive oil or cold cream after drying.
      (2)   If the eyes are accidentally splashed or rubbed with the hand after
handling the solvent, flushing with large quantities of water at room
temperature should be done immediately and a doctor consulted.
      (3)   Do not administer adrenalin to persons accidentally overcome by the
solvents.
      (4)   A sign prohibiting spotting of garments with flammable solvents
shall be posted.
         (Ord. 1961-394.  Passed 12-12-61.)
713.07  MACHINE DESIGN AND MAINTENANCE.
   (a)   All machines shall be designed so as to prevent the completion of the
cleaning cycle and the removal of solvent laden garments.  A solvent vapor
sensing device is recommended.
   (b)   Machines shall interlock to prevent the opening of the loading door
when the cycle has started.  The loading door shall not be openable in the
event of power failure.
   (c)   All equipment shall be kept in repair, solvent controlled to maintain
satisfactory cleaning and a log of repairs and filter cleaning recorded by
experienced maintenance personnel instructed on the solvent hazards.
(Ord. 1961-394.  Passed 12-12-61.)
713.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of
the fourth degree.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day
during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 715
Community Antenna Television Systems
715.01   Definitions.
715.02   Application procedure.
715.03   Granting of franchise; fee; collection of advertising revenue.
715.04   Franchise to Continental Cablevision.
715.05   Cablevision Advisory Committee.
715.06   Cable television customer protection services.
715.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Granting franchises - see CHTR. Art.
X, Sec.
7
Franchises - see Prelim.,
Table. A.
Theft of services - see GEN. OFF.
545.05
715.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Community antenna television system" means a television reception
system capable of receiving, transmitting and distributing voices, sound,
signals, pictures, visual images or any other type of closed circuit
transmission or signal transmission by means of electrical impulses throughout
the entire community or a significant portion of the community.
   (b)   "Person" means any person, firm, corporation or association wishing to
engage in the community antenna television systems business within the City.
      (Ord. 1966-112.  Passed 5-10-66.)
715.02  APPLICATION PROCEDURE.
   Any person desiring to operate a community antenna television system within
the City shall apply to Council for the granting of a franchise prior to
commencing any construction or installation for the operation of such a system.
   The application shall be made by letter directed to the Clerk of Council.
   Council, when it deems it necessary may require the applicant to submit
plans and specifications for the installation of the applicant's proposed
system showing location of all physical installations proposed.
(Ord. 1966-112.  Passed 5-10-66.)
715.03  GRANTING OF FRANCHISE; FEE; COLLECTION OF ADVERTISING REVENUE.
   (a)   Subject to subsection (b) hereof, when the proposed application and
plan for the installation and erection of a community antenna television system
is in the best interest of the public peace, health, safety and general welfare
of the inhabitants of the City, Council may grant a franchise to the person
applying for the operation of the system for any period of time not in excess
of twenty-five years.  The granting of a franchise shall be by ordinance duly
adopted by Council and approved by the Mayor, and shall contain therein the
terms and conditions of the franchise and may include a franchise fee of five
percent (5%) or less payable to the City from the franchise holder.  The City
may also collect advertising revenue from video and cable operators in the
amount as specified in the Franchise Agreement.
   (b)   In accordance with the requirements of Ohio R.C. 1332.32, and subject
to its taking effect, all video service providers providing video service in
the City pursuant to a video service authorization obtained from the Director
of the Ohio Department of Commerce shall pay  Video Service Provider Fees (“VSP
Fees”) in the amount of five percent (5%) of gross revenues received from
providing video service in the City, which gross revenue base shall include
advertising revenues as permitted and defined by Ohio R.C. 1332.32(B)(2)(g). 
The VSP Fee shall be paid quarterly, not sooner than forty-five (45) days nor
later than sixty (60) days after the end of each calendar quarter.
   (c)   The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed, upon receipt of notice
from a video service provider that it will begin providing video service in the
City pursuant to a state-issued video service authorization, to provide such
video service provider with notice of the VSP Fee as determined by this Council
above, which notice may be given by overnight (return receipt) or certified
mail or other manner of delivery no later than ten (10) days from receipt of
the provider’s notice.  (Ord. 2007-108.  Passed 10-9-07.)
   
715.04  FRANCHISE TO CONTINENTAL CABLEVISION.
   Council hereby grants a franchise to Continental Cablevision of Ohio, Inc.,
subject to  terms and conditions found in "Exhibit A" attached to original
Ordinance 1979-196 and incorporated herein by reference as if set out at length
herein.
(Ord. 1979-196.  Passed 10-23-79.)
715.05  CABLEVISION ADVISORY COMMITTEE.
   There is hereby established a Cablevision Advisory Committee to act as an
informational base for answers to questions, direction for needed response and
various other duties involving the governmental channel.  The general
guidelines for the Cablevision Advisory Committee are as follows:
   (a)   Selection.  The Committee shall consist of five members, chosen by the
Planning Committee of Council and shall serve at the pleasure of the Planning
Committee.
   (b)   Structure.  The Committee shall select one of its members to serve as
chairman and one member to serve as secretary.  The Committee secretary shall
be responsible for the taking of accurate minutes of all meetings of the
Committee and shall file a copy of such minutes with the Clerk of Council
within two weeks following the meeting.
   (c)   Term.  One term shall consist of two years commencing February 1, 1982
and every two years thereafter.  Any person appointed to fill a vacancy shall
serve the balance of the two-year term.  All terms shall end on the anniversary
date and all new and/or continuing members shall be appointed no later than the
first meeting of the Planning Committee following the anniversary date.
   (d)   Schedule of Meetings.  The Committee shall meet a minimum of once each
month to discuss matters related to this responsibility.
   (e)   Compensation.  Membership on this Committee shall be on a voluntary
basis only, and no member shall be monetarily compensated for time or travel.
   (f)   Qualifications.  All Committee members shall be residents of the City
and no member may have an affiliation with or interest in Continental
Cablevision of Ohio, which is the current contract holder providing cablevision
services to the City.
   (g)   Duties.  The general duties of the Committee are as follows:
      (1)   Each member of the Committee shall become familiar with the
contract between Continental Cablevision and the City for the purposes of:
         A.   Identifying areas of the contract which may be in question or
which may not be being adhered to by either party to the contract;
         B.   Clarifying for the Planning Committee any points and questions
raised regarding cablevision services, rates, etc., as provided by the
contract; and
         C.   Referring citizens needing additional information or assistance
to the Planning Committee.
      (2)   Coordinate local interest programming which is brought to the City
for transmission via the governmental access channel by the general public. 
All programs for which such access is requested shall be evaluated by the
Committee as being for the general good before accepted for scheduling.
      (3)   Generate and/or encourage the generation of programs of local
interest.
         (Ord. 1981-213.  Passed 11-10-81.)
715.06  CABLE TELEVISION CUSTOMER PROTECTION SERVICES.
   (a)   The cable operator shall be subject to the following customer service
standards:
      (1)   Cable System Office Hours and Telephone Availability.
         A.   The cable operator shall maintain a local, toll-free or collect
call telephone access line which will be available to its subscribers twenty-
four hours a day, seven days a week.  Trained company representatives shall be
available to respond to customer telephone inquiries during normal business
hours and a professional answering service will answer calls thereafter.
         B.   Under normal operating conditions, telephone answer time by a
customer representative, including wait time, shall not  exceed thirty seconds
when the connection is made.  If the call needs to be transferred, transfer
time shall not exceed thirty seconds.  These standards shall be met no less
than ninety percent (90%) of the time under normal operating conditions,
measured on a quarterly basis.
         C.   The operator shall not be required to acquire equipment or
perform surveys to measure compliance with the telephone answering standards
above unless an historical record of complaints indicates a clear failure to
comply.
         D.   Under normal operating conditions, the customer shall receive a
busy signal less than three percent (3%) of the time.
         E.   Customer service center and bill payment locations shall be open
at least during normal business hours and shall be conveniently located. 
         F.   The normal hours of operation at the Eastlake customer office
shall be Monday through Wednesday 10:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. and Thursday and
Friday 10:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.
      (2)   Installations, outages and service calls.  Under normal operating
conditions, each of the following four standards shall be met no less than
ninety-five percent (95%) of the time measured on a quarterly basis:
         A.   Standard installations shall be performed within seven business
days after an order has been placed.  "Standard installation" means those that
are located up to 125 feet from the existing distribution system.
         B.   Excluding conditions beyond the control of the operator, the
cable operator shall begin working on service interruptions promptly and in no
event later than twenty-four hours after the interruption becomes known.  The
cable operator shall begin actions to correct other service problems the next
business day after notification of the service problem.
         C.   The appointment window alternatives for installations, service
calls and other installation activities shall be either a specific time or, at
maximum, a four-hour time block during normal business hours.  (The operator
may schedule service calls and other installation activities outside of normal
business hours for the express convenience of the customer.)
         D.   An operator may not cancel an appointment with a customer after
the close of business on the business day prior to the scheduled appointment.
         E.   If a cable operator representative is running late for an
appointment with a customer and will not be able to keep the appointment as
scheduled, the customer shall be contacted.  The appointment shall be
rescheduled, as necessary, at a time which is convenient for the customer.
      (3)   Communications between cable operators and cable subscribers.
         A.   Notification to subscribers.
            1.   The cable operator shall provide written information on each
of the following areas at the time of installation of service, at least
annually to all subscribers and at any time upon request:
               a.   Products or services offered;
               b.   Prices and options for programming services and conditions
of subscription to programming and other services;
               c.   Installation and service maintenance policies;
               d.   Instructions on how to use the cable services;
               e.   Channel positions of programming carried on the system; and
               f.   Billing and complaint procedures, including the address and
telephone number of the local franchise authority's cable office.
            2.   Customers shall be notified of any changes in rates,
programming services or channel positions as soon as possible through
announcements on the cable system and in writing.  Notice shall be given to
subscribers a minimum of thirty days in advance of such changes if the change
is within the control of the cable operator.  In addition, the cable operator
shall notify subscribers thirty days in advance of any significant changes in
other information required by the preceding paragraph.
         B.   Billing.
            1.   Bills shall be clear, concise and understandable.  Bills shall
be fully itemized, with itemizations including, but not limited to, basic and
premium service charges.  Bills shall also clearly delineate all activity
during the billing period, including optional charges, rebates and credits.
            2.   In case of a billing dispute, the cable operator shall respond
to a written complaint from a subscriber within thirty days.
         C.   Refunds.  Refund checks shall be issued promptly, but no later
than either:
            1.   The customer's next billing cycle following resolution of the
request or thirty days, whichever is earlier; or
            2.   The return of the equipment supplied by the cable operator if
service is terminated.
         D.   Credits.  Credits for service shall be issued no later than the
customer's next billing cycle following the determination that a credit is
warranted.  Credits shall be automatically given for all service interruptions
as soon as the cable operator is informed of the interruption by the
subscriber.  A separate telephone call to ask for the credit shall no longer be
necessary.
      (4)   Late fees.  Late fee charges shall be the same as other utility
companies charge in this area, but not greater than 1.5% per month on the
outstanding balance.  No other late fee shall be charged.
      (5)   Definitions.
         A.   "Normal business hours" means those hours during which most
similar businesses in the community are open to serve customers.  In all cases,
"normal business hours" includes some evening hours at least one night per week
and/or some weekend hours.
         B.   "Normal operating conditions" means those service conditions
which are within control of the cable operator.  Those conditions which are not
within the control of the cable operator include, but are not limited to,
natural disasters, civil disturbances, power outages, telephone network
outages, and severe or unusual weather conditions.  Those conditions which are
ordinarily within the controls of the cable operator include, but are not
limited to, special promotions, pay-per-view events, rate increases, regular
peak or seasonal demand periods and maintenance or upgrade of the cable system.
         C.   "Service interruption" means the loss of picture or sound on one
or more cable channels.
   (b)   The foregoing cable television customer service standards shall be
effective at the earliest time permitted by law.
(Ord. 1996-173.  Passed 6-11-96.)
715.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Any person who commences the construction, installation or operation
of a community antenna television system within the City without first having
been awarded a lawful franchise pursuant to the terms and conditions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree.  A separate offense
shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues.
   (b)   The penalty and remedy for a violation of the standards as set forth
in Section
715.06 shall be as follows:
      (1)   For service interruptions as defined above, automatic credit or
refund, equal to not less than ten dollars ($10.00), shall be provided to any
and all affected subscribers;
      (2)   For any violation of the above standards, specific performance and
reimbursement to the franchising authority for all legal and/or administrative
expenses in compelling specific performance;
      (3)   Intentional violations of the above standards not corrected within
thirty days shall be regarded as a failure to perform a material term of the
franchise agreement and shall be considered within the franchise performance
evaluation portion of the franchise renewal process;
      (4)   Any other penalty or remedy afforded by local, state or federal law
or regulation.
         (Ord. 1993-209.  Passed 12-14-93.)
CHAPTER 716
Wireless Communication Tower Facilities Franchise
716.01   Definitions.
716.02   Application procedure.
716.03   Granting of franchise; fee.
716.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Granting franchises - see CHTR. Art.
X, Sec.
7
Franchises - see PRELIM
. Table A
Wireless communication towers - see P. & Z. Ch.
1158
716.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   “Wireless communication tower facility” means a facility consisting of
the equipment and structure involved in receiving telecommunications or radio
signals from a mobile radio communication source and transmitting those signals
to a central switching computer which connects the mobile unit with the land
based telephone lines.
   (b)   “Person” means any person, firm, corporation or association wishing to
engage in the mobile radio communications business within the City.
(Ord. 1997-116.  Passed 7-8-97.)
716.02  APPLICATION PROCEDURE.
   Any person desiring to operate a wireless communication tower facility
within the City shall apply to Council for the granting of the franchise prior
to commencing any construction or installation for the operation of such a
facility.
   The application shall be made by letter directed to the Clerk of Council.
   Council, when it deems it necessary, may require the applicant to submit
plans and specifications for the installation of the applicant’s proposed
facility showing location of all physical installations proposed.
(Ord. 1997-116.  Passed 7-8-97.)
716.03  GRANTING OF FRANCHISE; FEE.
   When satisfied that the proposed application and plan for the installation
and erection of a wireless communications tower facility is in the best
interest of the public peace, health, safety and general welfare of the
inhabitants of the City, Council may grant a franchise to the person applying
for the operation of the system for any period of time not in excess of twenty-
five years.  The granting of a franchise shall be by ordinance duly adopted and
approved by the Mayor and shall contain thereon the terms and conditions of the
franchise and may include a franchise fee payable to the City from the
franchise holder.
(Ord. 1997-116.  Passed 7-8-97.)
716.99  PENALTY.
   Any person who commences the construction, installation or operation of a
wireless communications tower facility within the City without first having
been awarded a lawful franchise pursuant to the terms and conditions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree.
(Ord. 1997-116.  Passed 7-8-97.)
CHAPTER 717
Electrical Equipment and Fire Extinguisher Sales
717.01   Electrical equipment sales.
717.02   Fire extinguisher sales.
717.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
National Electrical Code - see BLDG. Ch.
1333
717.01  ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT SALES.
   (a)   No person, firm or corporation shall sell, offer or expose for sale
within the City any electrical material, equipment, fixture, appliance or
device which does not bear an Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc. or Factory
Mutual Engineering Division seal of approval, or which has been declared by the
Fire Chief or his duly designated inspector to be unsafe for use because of
design, construction, wiring or assembly.
   (b)   The Fire Chief or his duly designated inspector is hereby authorized
to inspect all electrical materials, equipment, fixtures, appliances or devices
sold, or offered or exposed for sale within the City and to determine whether
they are safe or unsafe for use because of design, construction, wiring or
assembly.  If he finds any such material unsafe, he shall give notice of the
finding to the person selling or offering or exposing the same for sale, and no
person shall be guilty of violating subsection (a) hereof unless written notice
has been given to him or his employer or to the person in charge of the place
where the article is sold, offered or exposed for sale.
(Ord. 1970-57.  Passed 5-14-70.)
717.02  FIRE EXTINGUISHER SALES.
   (a)   No person, directly or through an agent, shall sell or offer for sale
in the City any make, type or model of extinguisher, either new or used, unless
such make, type or model of extinguisher has first been tested and is approved
and labeled by the Factory Mutual Engineering Division, Underwriters'
Laboratories, Inc. or other testing laboratory approved by the Fire Marshal as
providing adequate and reliable tests and examination.  No person, directly or
through an agent, shall deliver or make available for use in the City any make,
type or model of extinguisher which is not first tested and/or serviced as
required in the standards of the National Fire Protection Association entitled
"Installation, Maintenance and Use of Portable Fire Extinguishers", NFPA No.
10-1981, copies, which are filed in the office of the Clerk of Council and
which regulations hereby are adopted and made by reference a part of this
section.
   (b)   No person, directly or through an agent, shall sell or offer for sale
in the City any make, type or model of vaporizing liquid fire extinguisher,
whether laboratory approved or not, except for use on a motor carrier as
authorized by the law of this State and the laws of the United States relating
to motor carriers.
(Ord. 1963-284.  Passed 12-30-63.)
717.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which no other
penalty is provided is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
   (b)   Whoever violates Section
717.02 is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree for a first offense, and
a misdemeanor of the third degree for a subsequent offense.  A separate offense
shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues.
