CHAPTER 721
Junk Shops and Yards
721.01   License required.
721.02   License application; duties of licensee.
721.03   License fee.
721.04   Denial of license.
721.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Secondhand dealers - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4737
721.01  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall engage in operating a junk shop or junk yard without first
having obtained a license to do so, from the Chief Building Official.
(Ord. 1950-5.  Passed 1-16-50.)
721.02  LICENSE APPLICATION; DUTIES OF LICENSEE.
   Each applicant shall state the name of each and every person interested in
the junk shop or junk yard, the proposed or present location of the same, and
the amount of ground and building space to be occupied in its operation.  Each
licensee shall make monthly reports of all vehicles purchased or left upon the
premises, the motor serial number, make, type of body, model and manufacturer's
name, and the name and address of each owner from whom a vehicle is purchased
or received.  The operator of the junk yard or shop shall keep and maintain a
list of all property of any nature whatsoever which comes into his possession,
which shall at all times be open to inspection by any police officer of the
City.
(Ord. 1950-5.  Passed 1-16-50.)
721.03  LICENSE FEE.
   The applicant shall pay a license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per
year.  The license shall expire December 31 of each year, and there shall be no
pro rata reduction of the fee for part of a year, nor shall there be any refund
in event the licensee discontinues the business before the last day of any year
for which the license is issued.
(Ord. 1950-5.  Passed 1-16-50.)
721.04  DENIAL OF LICENSE.
   No license shall be issued to any applicant when the location of the shop or
yard will be injurious to the health, safety, comfort, convenience or general
welfare of the neighborhood in which it is proposed to be operated.
(Ord. 1950-5.  Passed 1-16-50.)
721.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor for the first offense, and a misdemeanor of the fourth degree for a
subsequent offense.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day
during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 731
Mechanical Amusement Devices
731.01   Definition.
731.02   License required.
731.03   Application for license.
731.04   Percentage of tax; issuance of license; fee.
731.05   Revocation of license; seizure.
731.06   Appeal.
731.07   Rewards, prizes or replaying of tokens prohibited.
731.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Gambling - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
517
Making or using slugs - see GEN. OFF.
545.11
Tampering with coin machines - see GEN. OFF.
545.12
731.01  DEFINITION.
   As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise indicates:
   (a)   "Mechanical amusement device" means any machine or device which, upon
the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disc, may be operated by the
public generally for use as a game, entertainment or amusement, whether or not
registering a score.  It shall include such devices as jukeboxes, marble
machines, pinball machines, skill ball, mechanical grab machines and all games,
operations or transactions similar thereto under whatever name they may be
indicated.  It shall also include machines which, as the result of the
depositing of a coin, afford a commodity which has been determined by the
Surgeon General of the United States to be harmful to health.
   (b)   "Person" includes the following:  any person, firm, corporation or
association which owns any such machine; the person, firm, corporation or
association in whose place of business any such machine is placed for use by
the public; the person, firm, corporation or association having control over
such machines.
      (Ord. 1977-108.  Passed 6-14-77.)
731.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, either as owner, lessee or agent for another, shall keep,
possess, use, exhibit or operate any mechanical amusement device for gain,
unless such device displays in a prominent place the name and business address
of the person owning the device, and unless a license has first been secured
from the Director of Public Safety.  No license shall be issued for the
operation of any games or devices which are or may readily be used in any
manner or form as a gambling device or as a game of chance.
(Ord. 1977-108.  Passed 6-14-77.)
731.03  APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Application for a license for a mechanical amusement game or device shall be
made to the Chief of Police on forms provided by him and shall set forth the
name, residence and business addresses of the exhibitor of the device and the
place where the device is to be exhibited.
   The Chief of Police shall cause an investigation to be made of the applicant
for a license and of the premises wherein the games and devices are to be
operated.  The Safety Director shall have authority to approve or reject any
application for a license.
(Ord. 1977-108.  Passed 6-14-77.)
731.04  PERCENTAGE OF TAX; ISSUANCE OF LICENSE; FEE.
   (a)   Percentage of Tax.  The owner of the amusement device will be
responsible for submitting three percent (3%) of the dollars generated from any
and all amusement devices licensed for use within the City limits.  Tax amounts
will be paid to the Tax Department on or before the fifteenth of the following
month.  Failure to remit the tax due will be a violation of this section and
whoever violates any provision of this section will be denied a device use
permit in future years.  (Ord. 2008-042.  Passed 6-24-08.)
   (b)   Issuance of License; Fee.  Each application for a license for a
mechanical amusement device shall be referred to the Chief of Police, who, when
satisfied after investigation that the applicant is of good moral character,
and that all prior taxes have been submitted and paid timely, shall endorse his
approval on the application and return it to the Director of Public Safety. 
Thereupon and not otherwise, the Director of Public Safety may, upon the
payment of an inspection fee in the amount of twenty dollars ($20.00) for each
amusement device, issue to the applicant a license for such number of devices
as have been requested and approved.  The license shall be displayed at all
times in a prominent place on the licensed premises.  All licenses shall be
issued for a period not to exceed one year and shall expire on January 21 of
each year.  If a license is issued for less than one year, the inspection fee
shall be prorated on a quarterly basis.  No person shall exhibit a greater
number of devices than are authorized by the license issued for such premises. 
No license may be transferred from one location to another.
(Ord. 1997-074.  Passed 4-8-97.)
731.05  REVOCATION OF LICENSE; SEIZURE.
   The Director of Public Safety shall revoke any mechanical amusement device
license for any violation by the licensee of any of the provisions of this
chapter, including the exhibition of any device contrary to the provisions of
Section
731.07.  The Director and his deputies are authorized, without any order of any
court, to seize any mechanical amusement device exhibited contrary to the
provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 1977-108.  Passed 6-14-77.)
731.06  APPEAL.
   In case of the refusal of the Director of Public Safety to issue a
mechanical amusement device license, or the revocation by him of any such
license, the applicant or licensee may appeal from the order to the Board of
Appeals composed of the Director of Law, Director of Public Safety, Director of
Finance or any members of their respective departments who may be delegated to
act for them.  Notice of the appeal shall be in writing and shall be filed with
the Director of Public Safety within ten days after the making of the order
refusing to issue or revoking the license.  The Board of Appeals shall fix a
time, not later than fifteen days thereafter, for the hearing of the appeal, at
which hearing all parties interested shall be afforded an opportunity to be
heard and the Board of Appeals shall approve, modify or annul the order from
which the appeal has been perfected and the findings of the Board of Appeals
shall be conclusive on all parties thereto.  (Ord. 1977-108.  Passed 6-14-77.)
731.07  REWARDS, PRIZES OR REPLAYING OF TOKENS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall offer or give rewards or prizes of any kind, based upon the
score obtained or the result of operation of a mechanical amusement device, or
redeem for cash, merchandise or other thing of value, any token, slug or other
evidence of the result of operation of the device, or replay, or permit to be
replayed the device by means of any token, slug or other evidence of the result
of operation of the device.
   Any device which the licensee or exhibitor, or the agent or employee
thereof, knowingly permits to be used in violation of this section shall be
subject to immediate seizure by any law enforcement officer of the City, and
any person violating any provision of this section shall be subject to the
penalty in Section
731.99.
(Ord. 1977-108.  Passed 6-14-77.)
731.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or
on which such violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 1977-108.  Passed 6-14-77.)
CHAPTER 741
Peddlers, Solicitors and Canvassers
741.01   Definitions.
741.02   Peddling, soliciting and canvassing  at private residences.
741.03   Registration and permit.
741.04   Police Division permit required to obtain license.
741.05   Information required; license issuance.
741.06   License fees.
741.07   Exemption from license and fee; application for charitable
solicitation license.
741.08   Employees of exempt peddlers,  solicitors or canvassers; license; fee.
741.09   Exemptions generally.
741.10   Display of license and photograph.
741.11   Display of permit.
741.12   Hours of business.
741.13   Prohibited areas.
741.14   Misrepresentation.
741.15   Disturbing the peace; noise.
741.16   Sale in parks or on public grounds.
741.17   Transfer of license or permit.
741.18   Suspension or revocation of license.
741.19   Unlicensed peddler, solicitor or canvasser; license fee.
741.20   Ice cream truck regulations.
741.21   Appeal procedure.
741.22   Renewals.
741.23   Do not knock registry.
741.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61 et seq.
Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1716
Sale of goods and services within right of way of interstate and state highways
- see Ohio R.C. 5515.07
Merchandise may not be displayed on sidewalk or in street - see TRAF.
311.05
Littering - see GEN. OFF.
521.08
Trespassing - see GEN. OFF.
541.05
Christmas tree sales - see BUS. REG. Ch.
711
741.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Person" means an individual, association of individuals, partnership,
corporation, society and Massachusetts or common-law trust.
   (b)   "Peddle" means to sell and make immediate delivery, or offer for sale
and immediate delivery, any goods, wares or merchandise in possession of the
seller, at any place within the City other than from a fixed place of business.
   (c)   "Peddler" means any person who peddles, as defined in subsection (b)
hereof.
   (d)   "Solicit" means to sell or take orders, or offer to sell or take
orders for goods, wares or merchandise for future delivery, or for services to
be performed at any place within the City other than a fixed place of business.
   (e)   "Solicitor" means any person who solicits, as defined in subsection
(d) hereof.
   (f)   "Canvasser" means any person, whether a resident of the City or not,
including an employee or agent of another, travelling either by foot,
automobile, truck or some other type of conveyance, who engages in the practice
of going door-to-door, house-to-house or along any streets within the City:
      (1)   Selling or taking orders for or offering to sell or take orders for
goods, merchandise, wares or other items of value for present or future
delivery or services to be performed in the future for commercial purposes.
      (2)   Requesting contribution of funds, property or anything of value, or
the pledge of any type of future donation, or selling or offering without
remuneration, any type of property, including but not limited to goods,
tickets, books or pamphlets for charitable, religious or other noncommercial
purposes.
   (g)   "Canvassing activities" means the practices of canvassers as listed in
subsection (f) hereof.
   (h)   "Charitable organization" means a nonprofit charitable, benevolent,
philanthropic, patriotic, educational, religious or eleemosynary organization.
      (Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.02  PEDDLING, SOLICITING AND CANVASSING AT PRIVATE RESIDENCES.
   No person, not having obtained a permit or license or both, shall go in or
upon residential property, ring a doorbell or knock on a door of a private
residence, including an apartment, not having been requested or invited to do
so by the owner, occupant or lessee of such private residence or apartment, for
the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares or merchandise or
peddling, hawking or canvassing the same.  (Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.03  REGISTRATION AND PERMIT.
   No person, except those exempted under Section
741.09, shall peddle, solicit or canvass without having complied with the
following requirements:
   (a)   Every person who desires to peddle, solicit or canvass, shall
register, in a registration book provided for that purpose of the Police
Division, his name and address; the name and address of the person whom he
represents; the names and addresses of at least two references as to his moral
character, honesty and integrity; a brief description of the nature of the
business in which he is engaged, and the kinds of goods or property to be
peddled, solicited or canvassed, if any.  Such person shall furnish his
fingerprints and thumb prints, to be taken by the Police Division.
   (b)   Such registration shall be valid for a period of one year, and such
person must register at the end of each one year period.
   (c)   As evidence of compliance with the provisions of this section, the
Police Division shall issue, within five days, to each person who complies, a
permit which shall show the name and address of such person, the name of the
person he represents or by whom he is employed, if any, and the kind of goods
or property to be peddled, solicited or canvassed.
      (Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.04  POLICE DIVISION PERMIT REQUIRED TO OBTAIN LICENSE.
   No person shall be issued a license by the Chief of Police unless such
person has been first issued a permit for peddling, soliciting or canvassing by
the Police Division or has obtained a clearance from the Law Department stating
that no license is required.
(Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.05  INFORMATION REQUIRED; LICENSE ISSUANCE.
   A solicitor's, peddler's or canvasser's license shall be issued by the Chief
of Police upon the applicant's complying with the following provisions:
   (a)   Giving his name, present address and his permanent address.
   (b)   Giving a brief description of the nature of business and the kinds of
goods or property to be peddled, solicited or canvassed.
   (c)   Paying the license fee required for the license.
   (d)   Giving the name and address of the licensed employer and exhibiting
credentials showing he is an authorized employee or representative of such
licensed employer, in the event the application is for an employee's license.
   (e)   Furnishing two photographs of himself of appropriate size, one of
which shall be attached at all times to the license and the other delivered to
the Police Chief for his files.
      (Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.06  LICENSE FEES.
   Every person desiring a solicitor's or peddler's license shall pay a license
fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per year, payable in advance.
(Ord. 1993-104.  Passed 5-25-93.)
741.07  EXEMPTION FROM LICENSE AND FEE; APPLICATION FOR CHARITABLE SOLICITATION
LICENSE.
   The following persons are not required to obtain a license or pay a license
fee, but shall obtain a permit from the Police Division as provided in Section
741.03 except that persons exempt under subsection (d) hereof are required to
follow the procedures contained in subsection (f) hereof:
   (a)   Any person soliciting, peddling or canvassing anything which such
person has personally manufactured or produced.
   (b)   Any farmer, poultryman or horticulturist soliciting, peddling or
canvassing his own produce.  This exemption applies only to such persons and
not to farmers, poultrymen or horticulturists who buy goods for resale, as well
as selling their own produce.
   (c)   Any person soliciting, peddling or canvassing for personal services to
be performed by the person so soliciting, peddling or canvassing.
   (d)   Any person soliciting, peddling, or canvassing or selling tickets for
any religious, charitable, school, educational or veterans' organization.
   (e)   Any peddling of or soliciting or canvassing for the sale of religious
or educational publications and books.
   (f)   Any charitable organization intending to use volunteers serving
without compensation to engage in canvassing or soliciting for the purposes of
such charitable organization within the City shall apply for a charitable
solicitation/canvasser license by filing with the Director of Public Safety an
application in writing sworn to by one of its officers or directors on a form
to be furnished by the Division of Public Safety, which application shall
include the following information:
      (1)   The name and address of the applicant organization.
      (2)   A statement that the applicant is a charitable organization as
defined in this section together with a brief description of the purposes of
the organization and the nature of the goods, property and services to be
inspected or sold, or for which orders are to be taken.
      (3)   The length of time for which the right to engage in canvassing or
solicitation is desired.
      (4)   The name, address and social security number of the person or
persons who will be in charge of the volunteer canvassers or solicitors within
the City.
      (5)   The name, address and social security number of the person or
persons who will be doing the actual volunteer canvassing or soliciting within
the City.
   The Director of Public Safety shall promulgate rules and regulations
regarding this application process.  When the Director of Public Safety is
satisfied that the applicant organization is a charitable organization and that
it will engage in canvassing or soliciting only for charitable, benevolent,
philanthropic, patriotic, educational, religious or eleemosynary purposes, he
shall issue a charitable solicitation/canvasser license to the applicant for
the remainder of the calendar year or for any lesser period of time as
requested in the application.
   Any license issued under the provisions of this section may be revoked by
the Director of Public Safety at any time that he determines that the
organization or individual is in violation of the terms and conditions of this
chapter.
   There shall be no fee charged or collected for the solicitation/canvasser
license issued to a charitable organization.
(Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.08  EMPLOYEES OF EXEMPT PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS OR CANVASSERS; LICENSE; FEE.
   No employee's license shall be issued under the provisions of Section
741.06(b) to any employee of any solicitor, peddler or canvasser exempted from
the payment of a license fee by the provisions of Section
741.07, provided, however, every employee of such solicitor, peddler or
canvasser shall obtain a charitable solicitation/canvasser license according to
the provisions contained in Section
741.07(f).
(Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.09  EXEMPTIONS GENERALLY.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to:
   (a)   The peddling, soliciting or canvassing of newspapers, ice, milk,
cream, butter, eggs, cheese, laundry, baked goods, dry cleaning or dairy
products other than popsicles, ice cream and frozen dairy products.
   (b)   Salesmen or agents for wholesale houses or firms who solicit orders
from or sell to retail dealers for resale, to manufacturers for manufacturing
purposes, or to bidders for public works or supplies.
      (Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.10  DISPLAY OF LICENSE AND PHOTOGRAPH.
   Every solicitor, peddler or canvasser licensed under this chapter shall have
his photograph attached to his license and shall have his license in his
immediate possession at all times.  When peddling, soliciting or canvassing, he
shall display the same upon demand of any police officer of the City and upon
demand of any person to whom he is peddling or soliciting or canvassing.
(Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.11  DISPLAY OF PERMIT.
   Every solicitor, canvasser or peddler, at all times while engaged in
peddling, soliciting or canvassing, shall have in his immediate possession the
permit issued to him under the provisions of this chapter, and when so
peddling, canvassing or soliciting shall display the same upon demand of any
police officer of the City and upon demand of any person to whom he is
peddling, soliciting or canvassing.
(Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.12  HOURS OF BUSINESS.
   No person shall peddle, canvass or solicit before 8:00 a.m. or after 5:00
p.m. of any day, with the exception that during the period starting with June
1, through and including September 1, a person may peddle, canvass or solicit
between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., and from 6:00 p.m. through 9:00
p.m.
   No ice cream vendor selling popsicles, frozen confections, etc., shall
peddle, solicit or canvass before 10:00 a.m. on any day.
(Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.13  PROHIBITED AREAS.
   No peddler, solicitor or canvasser for commercial purposes, or any person
pretending to be a peddler, solicitor or canvasser, for the purpose of
peddling, soliciting or canvassing or pretending to peddle, solicit or canvass,
shall ring the bell or knock at any building whereon there is painted, affixed
or otherwise displayed to public view any sign containing any or all of the
following words:  "No Peddlers", "No Solicitors", "No Agents" or "No
Canvassers" or which otherwise purports to prohibit peddling, soliciting or
canvassing on the premises.
(Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.14  MISREPRESENTATION.
   No peddler, solicitor or canvasser shall represent by words, writing or
action that he is some other peddler, solicitor or canvasser, that he is a
partner, employee or agent of any peddler, solicitor or canvasser, when in fact
he is not the partner, employee or agent of such peddler, solicitor or
canvasser, or that he is the employee, representative, agent or partner of any
person when in fact he is not the employee, representative, agent or partner of
such person.
(Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.15  DISTURBING THE PEACE; NOISE.
   No peddler, solicitor or canvasser shall cry his wares in a loud voice or
use any noise producing device, nor shall any peddler, solicitor or canvasser
commit any breach of the peace in crying his wares or soliciting, peddling or
canvassing the sale of his products.
(Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.16  SALE IN PARKS OR ON PUBLIC GROUNDS.
   No person shall sell or distribute any goods, wares or merchandise on the
streets or alleys or in the parks or other public grounds of the City.
(Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.17  TRANSFER OF LICENSE OR PERMIT.
   Licenses and permits shall not be assigned or transferred, nor shall they,
or either of them, be used by any person other than the person to whom they
were issued, except as herein provided:
   (a)   No person shall transfer, loan or permit the use of his license or
permit by any other person, except as herein provided.
   (b)   Where a person who is not himself soliciting, peddling or canvassing
has taken out a license for a bona fide employee, and such license is issued in
the names of the employer and the employee, the license may be transferred
subject to the following conditions:
      (1)   The license and the permit must be presented to the Chief of
Police;
      (2)   The permit is to be retained by the Chief of Police;
      (3)   A notation must be made upon the license to indicate its transfer
from one employee to another;
      (4)   The new employee must comply with the provisions of Section
741.03.  (Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.18  SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   (a)   Any license issued under this chapter may be suspended or revoked for
any of the following reasons:
      (1)   Fraud, misrepresentation or any false statement contained in the
application for a license;
      (2)   Fraud, misrepresentation or any false statement made in the course
of conducting peddling, soliciting or canvassing;
      (3)   Conducting peddling, soliciting or canvassing contrary to the
conditions of the license; or
      (4)   Conducting peddling, soliciting or canvassing activities in such a
manner as to create a public nuisance or constitute a danger to the public
health, safety or welfare.
   (b)   Upon suspension or revocation, the City shall deliver written notice
to the license holder stating the action taken and the reasons supporting such
action.  The written notice shall be delivered to the license holder's place of
business or mailed to the license holder's last known address.
(Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.19  UNLICENSED PEDDLER, SOLICITOR OR CANVASSER; LICENSE FEE.
   Conviction and punishment of any person for peddling, soliciting or
canvassing without a license shall not excuse or exempt such person from the
payment of any license fee due or unpaid at the time of such conviction, and
nothing in this chapter shall prevent criminal prosecution for any violation of
any provision of this chapter.
(Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.20  ICE CREAM TRUCK REGULATIONS.
   Any ice cream vendor licensed under Section
741.02 shall have his truck safety inspected by the Division of Police prior to
soliciting.  Along with the usual items viewed for vehicle safety, the truck
shall also be equipped with a sign that protrudes on the traffic side of the
street warning motorists when it is stopped and selling frozen confections. 
The truck shall also be equipped with six eight-inch flashing lights that will
be activated when vending is taking place.  The rear of the truck shall be
equipped with a sign saying "Slow Children" or "Caution Children".
   Ice cream vendors may only solicit business on the streets of the City
during the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m., and at no time shall the ringing
of any type of bell be permitted, the playing of music or sound of chimes.
   The truck shall be occupied with two employees at all times.  One employee
shall wear an orange fluorescent vest and be responsible for crossing children
across the street before and after their purchase has been made.
   The truck may not be used for business until satisfactorily passed by the
vehicle safety inspection.  If cause is brought forth by any citizen or police
officer, it may be reinspected.  Furthermore, all ice cream vending trucks
shall display the company name prominently on each side and the rear of each
truck.  No license shall be issued to any ice cream truck vendor until proof is
displayed that each truck has liability insurance in a minimum amount of five
hundred thousand dollars ($500,000).
(Ord. 1993-106.  Passed 6-8-93.)
741.21  APPEAL PROCEDURE.
   Any person aggrieved or damaged by a decision not to issue a license may,
within ten days after the denial or revocation of such license appeal to the
Court of Common Pleas of Lake County, Ohio.  Such appeal may be either on
questions of law or on questions of fact or on questions of law and fact.  Any
such appeal shall be governed by the provision of Ohio R.C. Chapter 2506.
(Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.22  RENEWALS.
   Licenses may be renewed, provided an application for renewal and license
fees are received by the City no later than the expiration date of the current
license.  Applications received after that date shall be processed as new
applications.  The City shall review each application for renewal to determine
that the applicant is in full compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
If the City finds that the application meets such requirements, the City shall
issue a new license.
(Ord. 1993-080.  Passed 4-27-93.)
741.23  DO NOT KNOCK REGISTRY.
   (a)   If requested by the City, and for as long as the Northeast Ohio Public
Energy Council (“NOPEC”) shall agree to do so, NOPEC shall establish and
maintain for the City a “Do Not Knock Registry” (“Registry”) and is authorized
to contact individuals on the Registry to distribute “Do Not Knock” stickers to
them at no cost to the City of Eastlake or the individuals and contact
individuals to update the list each year.
   (b)   The decision of whether to place a residence, house, apartment or
other dwelling on the “Do Not Knock Registry” shall be solely that of the
lawful possessor and occupant thereof.
   (c)   Any person in lawful possession and occupancy of any residence, house,
apartment or other dwelling in the City may request NOPEC to place or maintain
the address of his or her business, residence, house, apartment or other
dwelling on the Do Not Knock Registry, by submitting a request on a form
supplied by the City or by submitting a request online at www.blocktheknock.com
or at the Block the Knock community event which shall contain the following
information:
      (1)   The name of the person(s) completing the form;
      (2)   The complete address of the residence, house, apartment or other
dwelling to be placed on the Registry;
      (3)   The date the form was completed;
      (4)   A statement that in regards to the subject address, no peddlers or
solicitors shall knock, ring the doorbell, make noise or otherwise call for the
attention of the occupants at the subject address, in any manner; and
      (5)   Such other information that verifies the identity of the person(s)
completing the form as a lawful possessor and occupant as may be required by
the City.
   (d)   A residence, house, apartment or other dwelling, after being lawfully
placed on the “Do Not Knock Registry,” shall remain on said Registry until the
earliest of any of the following:
      (1)   The City or NOPEC receives notice of removal pursuant to subsection
(e) hereof; or
      (2)   The City or NOPEC receives formal notice that the person who
submitted the form pursuant to subsection (c) hereof is not or is no longer a
lawful possessor and occupant of the premises.
   (e)   Any person in lawful possession and occupancy of any residence, house,
apartment or other dwelling in the City may require the City or NOPEC to remove
his or her business, residence, house, apartment or other dwelling from the “Do
Not Knock Registry,” by submitting a separate Notice of Removal from said
Registry on a form supplied by the Chief of Police or NOPEC, or by submitting a
request online to www.blocktheknock.com which shall contain the following
information:
      (1)   The name and signature of the person(s) completing the form;
      (2)   The complete address of the business, residence, house, apartment
or other dwelling to be removed from the Registry;
      (3)   The date the form was completed;
      (4)   A statement that the residence, house, apartment or other dwelling
shall be removed from the “Do Not Knock Registry”; and
      (5)   Such other information that verifies the identity of the person(s)
completing the form as a lawful possessor and occupant as may be required by
the Chief of Police.
   (f)   The decision whether to place a residence, house, apartment or other
dwelling on the Peddlers and Solicitors “Do Not Knock Registry” shall be solely
that of the lawful possessor and occupant thereof and no official, employee or
other agent of the City shall interfere with that decision.
   (g)   The City will send notice to each registered address on the Registry,
in the form of a sticker, that the occupant must display on or near the main
entrance door or window, so that it is conspicuously visible to those
approaching the premises.
   (h)   A copy of the “Do Not Knock Registry” shall be made available to the
public during normal business hours of the City at the Eastlake Police
Department and shall be provided to every peddler or solicitor that is required
to obtain a permit from the City or required to register with the City pursuant
to this Chapter.
   (i)   By enacting this Chapter, Peddlers and Solicitors are on notice that a
Peddlers and Solicitors “Do Not Knock Registry” exists.  Each is responsible
for obtaining a copy of the Registry from the City prior to peddling or
soliciting in the City of Eastlake, which Registry shall also be made available
on the City’s website.
   (j)   Peddlers and Solicitors are prohibited from knocking on the door of
any residence, house, apartment or other dwelling that is listed on the
Registry or upon which a Do Not Knock sticker is conspicuously displayed on the
premises pursuant to Section
741.23(g) above.
   (k)   Provisions of the “Do Not Knock Registry” do not apply to persons
invited onto the property by the occupant of the premises, for the purposes of
peddling, soliciting or canvassing.
(Ord. 2018-012.  Passed 2-27-18.)
741.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates Sections
741.02 through
741.19 of this chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a first offense and
a misdemeanor of the fourth degree for any subsequent offenses.  A separate
violation of Sections
741.02 through
741.19 shall be deemed committed each day during or on which the violation
occurs or continues.
   Whoever violates Section
741.20 of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree for a
first offense, and a misdemeanor of the third degree for any subsequent
offenses.  A separate violation shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which the violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. 2003-067.  Passed 5-13-03.)
CHAPTER 743
Scavengers
743.01   Definitions.
743.02   License fee and conditions.
743.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Garbage, rubbish, refuse and recycling collection - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
965
743.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Person" means a natural person, corporation, partnership, limited
liability company or other entity.
   (b)   "Trash" means discarded rubbish, refuse, paper, rags, appliances,
furniture, scrap metal or other similar discarded material.
   (c)   "Scavenging" means the removal of trash from private or public
property for the purpose of using, selling, relocating or disposing of such
trash.
   (d)   "City trash collector" means the person who has contracted with the
City to provide trash collection services.
   (e)   "Recyclable materials" means materials that have been placed by the
owner thereof for collection by the City or the City trash collector and have
been identified, either by color of container or other means, as material
offered for recycling.
(Ord. 2013-054. Passed 8-27-13.)
743.02  LICENSE FEE AND CONDITIONS.
   (a)   No person shall engage in scavenging unless such person first obtains
a license (the "scavenger license") from the Safety Director or his or her
designated representative.  The fee for a scavenger license shall be fifteen
dollars ($15.00) per year.  All scavenger licenses shall expire on December 31
of the year of issuance.  There shall be no proration of the fee for a
scavenger license issued after the start of a calendar year.
   (b)   A condition of any scavenger license issued shall be that the licensee
agrees to scavenge between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. and to collect,
transport and dispose of trash in a sanitary manner so as not to create a
nuisance and to comply with all rules and regulations from time to time
promulgated by the Safety Director, which may include but not be limited to,
times and days for collections and designation of areas.
   (c)   Before a vehicle may be used in scavenging, the holder of the
scavenger license shall register such vehicle with the office of the Safety
Director.
   (d)   Any person issued a scavenger license shall display a copy of the
license in prominent sight on each vehicle used by such person in scavenging
identifying such person as a licensed scavenger and containing current contact
information for such person. 
   (e)   Any vehicle conveying or carrying trash shall be so constructed and
operated that its contents shall not spill or scatter upon any public or
private property.  Any person hauling or scavenging trash in or using an open
vehicle such as a truck or trailer shall cause the load to be covered with an
adequate tarpaulin or canvas so as to prevent any spilling or scattering of its
contents.
   (f)   After a person engaged in scavenging inspects and/or removes items of
trash, such person shall clean up any debris resulting from such person's
activities, return any uncollected trash to the bags or containers from which
they were removed and return the remaining trash to the condition existing
prior to such inspection and/or collection.
   (g)   No person shall remove or cause the removal of recyclable materials
from any lot, premises or public place that have been placed or deposited for
collection by the City or the City trash collector.
   (h)   This section shall not apply to:
      (1)   Any private individual removing or hauling trash from his or her
own premises;
      (2)   Any City employee within the performance of his duties with the
City;
      (3)   The City trash collector;
      (4)   Any private or public school.
         (Ord. 2013-054. Passed 8-27-13.)
743.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   The scavenger license of anyone who violates any provision of this
chapter or any rule or regulation issued pursuant to this chapter may be
revoked by the Safety Director.  Any person whose scavenger license has been
revoked pursuant to this section shall not be issued another scavenger license
for at least three (3) years from the date of revocation.
   (b)   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter or any rule or
regulation issued pursuant to this chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
(Ord. 2013-054. Passed 8-27-13.)
CHAPTER 751
Taxicabs
751.01   Definitions.
751.02   Administration and enforcement; transfer of license. 
751.03   License for vehicles; application.
751.04   Service requirements.
751.05   Number of hack licenses fixed.
751.06   Limitation on new hack licenses.
751.07   Inspection before licensing vehicles; rules.
751.08   Surety bond or liability insurance. 
751.09   License card.
751.10   Fees for licensing vehicles.
751.11   Inspection of licensed hacks.
751.12   Suspension or revocation of license.
751.13   Drivers' licenses; applications; regulations.
751.14   Examination of drivers.
751.15   Photograph of driver.
751.16   Form and terms of drivers' licenses.
751.17   Temporary permits; fees.
751.18   Driver's license certificate.
751.19   Renewal of drivers' licenses.
751.20   Fee for drivers' licenses.
751.21   Refusal to issue; suspension or revocation of drivers' licenses;
appeal.
751.22   Record of drivers' licenses.
751.23   Taximeters.
751.24   Rates of fare; receipts.
751.25   Prepayment of fare; conveyance of persons mandatory; first passenger's
priority
751.26   Disputed fares.
751.27   Fictitious information.
751.28   Employing unlicensed driver.
751.29   Exceptions.
751.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.22, 715.66
Power to establish stands and fix rates - see Ohio R.C. 715.25; TRAF.
305.04(l)
Operation equipment - see TRAF. Ch.
331, Ch.
337
751.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Taximeter" means a mechanical instrument or device by which the
charge for hire of a public hack is mechanically calculated, either for
distance traveled, for waiting time, or for both, and upon which the charges
are indicated.
   (b)   "Public hack" means a vehicle plying for hire, for which public
patronage is solicited upon the streets.
   (c)   "Coach" means a public hack so designed and constructed as comfortably
to seat, in the opinion of the Director of Public Safety, four or more persons
inside thereof.
   (d)   "Taxicab" means a coach driven by mechanical power, on which a
taximeter is affixed and each cab shall have a sign on top designating it as a
taxicab.
      (Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.02  ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT; TRANSFER OF LICENSE.
   The licensing and inspection of public hacks, the inspecting and sealing of
taximeters, the examining of applicants for a license to drive public hacks,
and the licensing of drivers, as hereinafter provided, and the enforcing of the
provisions of this chapter shall be under the control of the Director of Public
Safety.
   If a hack is disabled, disqualified for service or sold, the Safety Director
may at his discretion permit the use of a license granted for a public hack to
be transferred and used for another, provided the hack complies with the
provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.03  LICENSE FOR VEHICLES; APPLICATION.
   No public hack shall operate for hire upon the streets of the City without
obtaining a license from the Director of Public Safety after approval of
Council. The licenses shall be issued as of January 1, and shall expire on
December 31, next succeeding, unless sooner suspended or revoked by the Safety
Director with the consent and approval of Council. Application for a license
for a public hack shall be made by the owner, upon blank forms to be furnished
by the Safety Director. The application shall contain the full name and address
of the owner, the class of vehicle for which the license is desired, the length
of time the vehicle has been in use, the number of persons it is capable of
carrying, and the motor power thereof, together with the indemnity bond
required by Section
751.08.
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
 
751.04  SERVICE REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   No license shall be granted for the operation of a public hack for
hire upon the streets of the City unless and until the vehicle is equipped with
a two-way service radio which shall be maintained and kept in good working
order.
   (b)   No license shall be granted for the operation of a public hack for
hire in the City unless the operator provides taxicab service on a twenty-four
hour basis provided that those hours do not frequently require the operator to
run at a loss and/or require the licensed hack driver to work for less than
minimum wage.
   Failure to comply with the requirements of subsections (a) and (b) hereof is
cause for suspension or revocation of any license heretofore issued.
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.05  NUMBER OF HACK LICENSES FIXED.
   It is determined that ten licenses issued for the operation of public hacks
are sufficiently adequate to serve the need for the service of the City.
   In the event that Council determines that operation of additional cabs is
necessary to adequately serve the requirements for such transportation in the
City, the then licensed taxicab operator in the City shall have three months in
which to provide the additional cabs and service, as Council may determine, and
if he fails to do so another or others may be licensed to provide the services
required. 
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.06  LIMITATION ON NEW HACK LICENSES.
   No license for the operation of public hacks in excess of the limitation
prescribed by Section
751.05 shall be issued until Council by resolution declares that public
convenience and necessity requires the issuance of additional public hack
licenses in the number set forth in the resolution. Upon the adoption of the
resolution, approved by the Mayor, the Director of Public Safety is authorized
to issue the specified additional number of public hack licenses.
   Before the adoption of the resolution, Council shall provide for a public
hearing or hearings as may be necessary to determine whether public convenience
and necessity requires the issuance of additional public hack licenses, and the
number of public hack licenses which should be issued to meet the public
convenience and necessity. In determining whether public convenience and
necessity requires the issuance of any additional licenses for public hacks,
Council shall take into consideration:
   (a)   The number of public hacks then licensed;
   (b)   Whether the requirements of public convenience and necessity can be
met and complied with only by the issuance of additional licenses;
   (c)   The resulting effect upon the business of existing licenses and upon
the existing agencies of mass transportation;
   (d)   The effect upon traffic congestion and safety of the public using the
streets;
   (e)   The effect upon working conditions and wages or other compensation
paid to drivers of public hacks of existing licenses;
   (f)   The financial responsibility of the applicant; and
   (g)   Any other fact which Council may deem relevant.
   No finding of public convenience and necessity is required for the issuance
of licenses within the limitation of Section
751.05, and holders of existing licenses are entitled without such finding of
convenience and necessity to retain their then existing licenses and secure
renewals thereof upon the payment of the annual license fees.
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.07  INSPECTION BEFORE LICENSING VEHICLES; RULES.
   When licenses or renewals of existing licenses are issued for any public
hacks which may have been disabled, disqualified, sold or may otherwise not be
available at the time of the granting of the licenses, no vehicle which may
thereafter be acquired for use in connection with any licenses shall be placed
in operation until it has been thoroughly and carefully inspected and examined
and found to be in a thoroughly safe condition for the transportation of
passengers; clean, fit, of good appearance, and well painted and varnished. The
applicant shall have any and all vehicles inspected by the Ohio State Patrol
and shall provide proof of a current inspection to the Director of Public
Safety or his/her designee. The Director of Public Safety or his/her designee
shall refuse to permit the operation of any vehicle, or, if already placed in
operation, revoke or suspend the operation of any vehicle found to be unfit or
unsuited for public patronage.  The Director of Public Safety or his/her
designee shall examine any taximeter attached to any public hack and see that
the same is accurate before permitting the use thereof upon any public hack
which may be placed in operation.  The Director of Public Safety or his/her
designee is authorized and empowered to establish reasonable rules and
regulations for the inspection of public hacks and their appurtenances,
construction, and condition or fitness.
(Ord. 2013-061. Passed 10-22-13.)
751.08  SURETY BOND OR LIABILITY INSURANCE.
   No person shall operate a public hack or other vehicle kept for hire or
permit such to be operated, nor shall any license be issued hereunder until the
applicant for a license deposits with the Director of Public Safety a policy or
a certificate of liability insurance for each hack for which a license is
sought, acceptable to and approved by Council and the Director of Law,
indemnifying the applicant in the sum of at least fifty thousand dollars
($50,000) for injury to one person, one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) for
injury to more than one person and ten thousand dollars ($10,000) for property
damage in any one accident through the operation of the public hack of the
applicant. The policy shall further contain a clause obligating the insurance
company to give ten days written notice to Council before cancellation of the
policy and shall further contain a provision for a continuing liability
thereunder to the full amount thereof, notwithstanding any recovery thereon.
Any license granted pursuant to Section
751.09 shall expire immediately upon the lapse or termination of the policy of
insurance required by this section.
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.09  LICENSE CARD.
   If, upon inspection, a public hack is found to be of lawful construction and
in proper condition, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and the
rules and regulations established hereunder, and upon the payment of the
license fees set forth in Section
751.10, the same shall be licensed by delivering to the owner a card of such
size and form as may be prescribed by the Director of Public Safety. The card
shall contain the official license number of the hack, together with the date
of inspection of same, and a statement to the effect that, in case of any
complaints, the Director shall be notified giving the license number of the
hack.  The card shall be signed by the Director, and shall contain blank spaces
upon which an entry shall be made of the date of every inspection of the
vehicle by the inspector.  The license card shall be of a distinctly different
color each year.  There shall also be printed upon the card the license number
of the vehicle, which card shall be conspicuously displayed within the hack as
prescribed by the Director.    (Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.10  FEES FOR LICENSING VEHICLES.
   The following license fee shall be paid.  For each public hack, ten dollars
($10.00) per year or part thereof.  (Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.11  INSPECTION OF LICENSED HACKS.
   The Director of Public Safety shall maintain constant vigilance over all
public hacks, to see that they are kept in a condition of continued fitness for
public use, and to this end the Director, through his inspectors, shall inspect
all public hacks from time to time as provided in Section
751.07, or on the complaint of any resident, as often as may be necessary.
Reports in writing of all inspections shall promptly be made to the Director.
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.12  SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   The Director of Public Safety may, and/or upon recommendation of Council
shall revoke or suspend any license granted under this chapter if the vehicle
is used for immoral or illegal purposes or if the vehicle is not in good
condition and appearance, and clean and safe. Licenses revoked for the reason
that the vehicle has been used for immoral or illegal business or purpose shall
not be reissued again, and licenses revoked because of the condition and
appearance of the vehicle shall not be reissued until the vehicle and its
appearance shall be put in fit condition for use by the public.  (Ord. 2000-
096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.13  DRIVERS’ LICENSES; APPLICATION; REGULATIONS.
   Every person driving a public hack must be licensed as such.  Each applicant
for a driver's license must:
   (a)   Be twenty-one years old or over, an American citizen or have declared
his intention to become such a citizen, and a bona fide resident of Lake
County, Cuyahoga County, or Geauga County.
   (b)   Be of sound physique, with good eyesight and not subject to epilepsy,
vertigo, heart trouble or any other infirmity of body or mind which might
render him unfit for safe operation of a public vehicle;
   (c)   Be able to read and write the English language;
   (d)   Be clean in dress and person, and not be addicted to the use of
intoxicating liquors or drugs;
   (e)   Produce, on forms to be provided by the Director of Public Safety, two
character references of persons not related to the applicant; and
   (f)   Fill out, upon a blank form to be provided by the Director, a
statement giving his full name, residence, places of residence for five years
previous to moving to his current address, age, color, height, birth, length of
time he has resided in the City, whether a citizen of the United States, places
of previous employment, whether married or single, whether he has ever been
arrested or convicted of a felony or misdemeanor, whether he has been summoned
to court, whether he has previously been licensed as a driver or chauffeur, and
if so, whether his license has ever been revoked, and for what cause, which
statement shall be signed and  sworn to by the applicant and filed with the
Director as a permanent record. Any false statement made by the applicant for a
license shall be promptly reported by the Director to the Prosecuting Attorney
of Lake County. Council shall establish such additional rules and regulations
covering the issuance of drivers' licenses, not inconsistent herewith, as may
be necessary and reasonable.
      (Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.14  EXAMINATION OF DRIVERS.
   Each applicant for a driver's license under the provisions of this chapter
shall be examined by a person designated by the Director of Public Safety as to
his knowledge of the provisions of this chapter, the traffic regulations and
the geography of the City, and, if the result of the examination is
unsatisfactory, he shall be refused a license. Each applicant must, if required
by the Director, demonstrate his skill and ability to safely handle his vehicle
by driving it through a crowded section of the City, accompanied by a police
officer.
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.15  PHOTOGRAPH OF DRIVER.
   Each applicant for a driver's license must file with his application three
unmounted, unretouched photographs of himself, in such position as the Director
of Public Safety may direct, taken within the thirty days preceding the filing
of his application. The photographs are to be of a size which may be easily
attached to his license, one of which shall be attached to his license when
issued and the others shall be filed with the application in the office of the
Director. The photograph shall be so attached to the license that it cannot be
removed and another photograph substituted without detection. Each licensed
driver shall, upon demand of an inspector of licenses, a policeman or a
passenger, exhibit his license and photograph for inspection. Where the
application for a license is denied, two copies of the photograph shall be
returned to the applicant by the Director. 
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.16  FORM AND TERMS OF DRIVERS' LICENSES.
   Upon satisfactory fulfillment of the foregoing requirements, there shall be
issued to the applicant a license, which shall be in such form as to contain
the photograph and name of the licensee. Licenses shall be issued as of January
1 in each and every year, and shall be valid to and including December 31 next
succeeding, unless previously revoked.
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.17  TEMPORARY PERMITS; FEES.
   Except when an extraordinary public emergency arises affecting
transportation of the public upon the streets within the City, no temporary
permits shall be issued. Temporary permits when issued shall be upon such terms
and conditions as Council shall provide, but such temporary permit shall in no
event be granted for a longer period than fifteen days, and may be renewable
for similar periods, from time to time as may be necessary with the approval of
Council.
   The fee for temporary permits shall be one dollar ($ 1.00) for the driver
and ten dollars ($10.00) for the hack or vehicle. 
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.18  DRIVER'S LICENSE CERTIFICATE.
   The Director of Public Safety shall issue a license certificate bearing the
photograph of the licensee, to each person licensed as the driver of a public
hack. The license certificate must, under penalty of suspension or revocation
of the license, be conspicuously displayed at all times in the vehicle operated
by the licensee and in the manner required by the Director. The certificate
shall be of such form and design as the Director shall prescribe.
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.19  RENEWAL OF DRIVERS' LICENSES.
   All renewals of drivers' licenses shall be made in accordance with the
procedure prescribed by Council.  (Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.20  FEE FOR DRIVERS' LICENSES.
   The following license fees shall be paid for drivers' licenses or for
renewals thereof:
   (a)   For each original license issued, twenty dollars ($20.00).
   (b)   For each renewal thereof, fifteen dollars ($15.00).
   (c)   For replacement of the driver's license certificate if the same is
lost, stolen, mutilated or destroyed, a fee of seven dollars and fifty cents
($7.50).
      (Ord. 2004-088.  Passed 9-14-04.)
751.21  REFUSAL TO ISSUE; SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF  DRIVERS' LICENSES;
APPEAL.
   A driver's license may be suspended or revoked at any time by the Director
of Public Safety upon his own initiative or upon the recommendation of the
Chief of Police. Before suspending or revoking the license the Director shall
afford the licensee the opportunity of a hearing upon the charges. The licensee
may appeal from the order in the following manner:
   In case of the refusal to issue a license or the revocation or suspension of
a license by the Director, the applicant or licensee may appeal from the order
to the Safety Committee of Council which shall constitute a Board of Appeals.
Notice of the appeal shall be in writing and shall be filed with the Safety
Committee within ten days after the making of the order. The Board of Appeals
within three days after the filing with the Board of such notice of appeal
shall proceed with the hearing of the appeal, at which hearing all parties
interested shall be afforded an opportunity to be heard, and the Board of
Appeals shall approve, modify or annul the order from which the appeal has been
perfected, and the finding of the Board of Appeals shall be final on all
parties thereto.
   A second suspension for the same reason, or in any case a third suspension
for any reason of a driver's license, shall operate as a revocation of the
license. No driver whose license has been revoked shall again be licensed as a
public hack driver in the City unless reasons are presented
which are satisfactory to Council. The Director shall notify the Police
Division of all suspensions or revocations of drivers' licenses.
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.22  RECORD OF DRIVERS' LICENSES.
   There shall be kept in the office of the Director of Public Safety a
complete record of each license issued to a driver, and of all renewals,
suspensions and revocations thereof, which record shall be kept on file with
the original application of the driver for a license.
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
   
751.23  TAXIMETERS.
   (a)   Attachment.  Every public hack driven by mechanical power, seating
four passengers or less shall have affixed thereto a taximeter.
   (b)   Inspection.  No license shall be issued to a public hack until its
taximeter has been inspected and found to be accurate.
   (c)   Inaccuracy.  No person shall use or permit to be used, upon any public
hack a taximeter which shall be in such condition as to be over five percent
(5%) incorrect, to the prejudice of any passenger.
   (d)   Wheel-Operated Prohibited.  No taximeter affixed to a public hack,
propelled by steam, gasoline, electricity or other motive power, shall be
operated from any wheel to which the power is applied.
   (e)   Illumination of Dial.  After sundown the face of every taximeter shall
be illuminated a suitable light, so arranged as to throw a continuous steady
light thereon.
   (f)   Case to be Sealed.  No person shall use or permit to be used or drive
for hire, a public hack equipped with a taximeter, the case of which is
unsealed, and not having its cover and gear intact.
   (g)   False Signal.  No driver of a public hack equipped with a taximeter or
other similar device, while carrying passengers, or under employment, shall
display the signal affixed to the taximeter or other similar device in such
position as to denote the vehicle is not employed, or in such position as to
denote that he is employed at a rate of fare different from that to which he is
entitled under the provisions of this chapter.
      
   (h)   Unapproved Taximeter.  No person shall drive a public hack to which is
attached a taximeter that has not been duly inspected and approved.
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.24  RATES OF FARE; RECEIPTS.
   (a)   The maximum rates of fare for taxicabs shall be as follows:
      (1)   For the first one-half mile or fraction thereof, four dollars
($4.00).
      (2)   For each succeeding one-fifth mile, or fraction thereof, sixty
cents ($.60).
                   (3)   For each taxicab employed by contract upon an hourly
rate, seventy dollars ($70.00) per hour.
      (4)   For time spent waiting for customer, sixty cents ($.60) per minute.
      (5)   Four  passengers shall ride for one fare; five or more passengers
in taxicab shall be charged  rates no more than five dollars ($5.00) for each
extra passenger (over four). 
(Ord. 2011-068.  Passed 5-10-11.)
   (b)   Public hacks may, upon request of passengers, accept employment on an
hourly rental period. When a public hack is so employed the fare to be charged
shall be computed from the time it leaves the nearest station of the owner to
the time of returning to the station nearest the point of dismissal.
   (c)   Upon request of a passenger, the owner, driver, chauffeur or other
person in charge or control of a public hack shall deliver to the person paying
for the hire of the same at the time of such payment a receipt therefor upon a
blank, the form of which is to be prescribed and approved by the Director of
Public Safety. The receipt shall contain in legible type or writing the name of
the owner, the driver's City license number, and other items for which a charge
is made, the total amount paid and the date of payment.
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.25  PREPAYMENT OF FARE; CONVEYANCE OF PERSONS  MANDATORY;  FIRST
PASSENGER'S PRIORITY.
   Every driver of a public hack shall have the right to demand payment of the
legal fare in advance, and may refuse employment unless so paid in advance, but
no driver of a public hack shall otherwise refuse or neglect to convey any
orderly person or persons upon request, anywhere in the City, unless previously
engaged. No driver of a licensed hack shall carry any other person than
passenger first employing a hack, without the express consent of the passenger.
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.26  DISPUTED FARES.
   All disputes as to the lawful rate or fare shall be determined by the police
officer in charge of the station, or the police officer nearest to where the
dispute is had.
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.27  FICTITIOUS INFORMATION.
   No person shall give fictitious information or practice any fraud,
misrepresentation or subterfuge in order to secure each or any license provided
for by this chapter.
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.28  EMPLOYING UNLICENSED DRIVER.
   No person operating public hacks shall employ as a driver of such public
hacks any person other than a driver duly licensed under the provisions of this
chapter.
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.29  EXCEPTIONS.
   Nothing in this chapter shall apply to motor vehicles used exclusively for
service at weddings, christenings or funerals. 
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
751.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Any owner or driver of a vehicle, not licensed in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter, or of a vehicle, the license of which has been
suspended or revoked, who engages in the business of using public hacks or
attempts to engage in such business, or solicits for hire passengers upon the
streets, is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
   (b)   Any person, not having been duly licensed as a public hack driver, or
any person whose license as a driver has been revoked, or any person whose
license has been suspended and who during the time of the suspension drives for
hire a public hack upon the streets, is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth
degree.
   (c)   Whoever violates any provision of Section
751.23, is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
   (d)   Whoever fails to comply with a determination of a police officer under
Section
751.26, is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree.
(Ord. 2000-096.  Passed 9-26-00.)
CHAPTER 753
Phosphate Pollution Control
753.01   Definitions.
753.02   Labeling.
753.03   Limitations.
753.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Restrictions on sale of detergents - see Ohio R.C. 6111.10
753.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   "Synthetic detergent" or "detergent" means any cleaning compound which
is available for household laundry use, which is composed of organic and
inorganic compounds, including soaps, water softeners, surface active agents,
dispersing agents, foaming agents, buffering agents, builders, fillers, dyes,
enzymes, and fabric softeners, whether in the form of crystals, powders,
flakes, bars, liquids, sprays or any other form.
   (b)   "Polyphosphate builder" or "phosphorus" means a water softening and
soil suspending agent made from condensed phosphates, including pyrophosphates,
triphosphates, tripolyphosphates, metaphosphates and glassy phosphates, used as
a detergent ingredient, but shall not include polyphosphate builders or
phosphorus which is essential for medical, scientific or special engineering
use.
   (c)   "Recommended use level" means that amount of synthetic detergent or
detergent which the manufacturer thereof recommends for use per wash load, at
which level such synthetic detergent or detergent will effectively perform its
intended function.
(Ord. 1981-188.  Passed 9-8-81.)
753.02  LABELING.
   No person, firm or corporation shall sell, offer or expose for sale, give or
furnish any synthetic detergent or detergent, whether in the form of crystals,
powders, flakes, bars, liquids, sprays or any other form, in the City from and
after January 1, 1982, unless the container, wrapper or other packaging thereof
shall be clearly labeled with respect to its polyphosphate builder or
phosphorous ingredient content clearly and legibly set forth thereon in terms
of percentage of phosphorus by weight, expressed as elemental phosphorus per
container, wrapper or other packaging thereof, as well as grams of phosphorus,
expressed as elemental phosphorus, per recommended use level.
(Ord. 1981-188.  Passed 9-8-81.)
753.03  LIMITATIONS.
   (a)   No person, firm or corporation shall sell, offer or expose for sale,
give or furnish any synthetic detergent or detergent containing more than five-
tenths percent (0.05%) of phosphorus by weight, expressed as elemental
phosphorus, within the City from and after January 1, 1981.
   (b)   The concentration of phosphorus by weight, expressed as elemental
phosphorus in any synthetic detergent or detergent shall be determined by the
current applicable method prescribed by the American Society for Testing and
Materials (A.S.T.M.).
(Ord. 1981-188.  Passed 9-8-81.)
753.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter, except when otherwise
specifically provided, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) nor more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the first offense,
and not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) for the second and each subsequent offense, in any 180-day
period, or shall be imprisoned not more than six months, or both.  A separate
and distinct offense shall be regarded as committed each day on which such
person shall continue or permit any such violation, or each day on which such
failure to comply is permitted to exist after notification thereof.
(Ord. 1981-188.  Passed 9-8-81.)
CHAPTER 755
Game Rooms
755.01   Definitions.
755.02   License required.
755.03   License application; approval or disapproval.
755.04   License fee; renewal.
755.05   Interior requirements.
755.06   Supervision.
755.07   Hours.
755.08   License revocation or suspension.
755.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Mechanical amusement devices - see BUS. REG. Ch.
731
Using slugs - see GEN. OFF.
545.11
Tampering - see GEN. OFF.
545.12
755.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Game room" means a building, room, enclosure, premises, place or
establishment in the City which contains more than six amusement devices, which
require coins or tokens for the operation of the amusement device; provided,
however, that any area of a school which may contain amusement devices shall
not be considered a game room.
   (b)   "Director of Public Safety" means the duly appointed or acting
Director of Safety of the City.
   (c)   "Amusement device" means a machine or device which, upon the insertion
of a coin or slug, operates or may be operated for use as a game, viewing of
movie or video, contest or amusement of any description, or which may be used
for any such game, contest or amusement; however, juke boxes are excluded.
      (Ord. 1994-080.  Passed 5-10-94.)
755.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, firm, corporation or association shall engage in the business of
operating a game room within the limits of the City without first having
applied for and obtained from the Director of Public Safety a license as
provided for in this chapter.
(Ord. 1981-077.  Passed 5-12-81.)
755.03  LICENSE APPLICATION; APPROVAL OR DISAPPROVAL.
   (a)   Application for the license shall be made to the Director of Public
Safety on forms to be prescribed by him, and shall state the name and address
of the applicant, if individuals, and if a firm or partnership, the names,
residences and occupations of the manager and each member of the firm or
partnership, and if a corporation the names of its officers and manager, and
such other information as the Director of Public Safety may require.  The
Director of Public Safety shall transmit such application for inspection and
investigation to the Chief of the Division of Inspections or his/her
representative, Chief of Fire and Chief of Police.  The Chief of the Division
of Inspections or his/her representative, Chief of Fire and Chief of Police
each shall, after such inspection and investigation as they may deem necessary,
make a report with their recommendation for approval or disapproval of such
application.  At the time the application is made there shall also be submitted
a plan showing parking and exits from the game room, this plan shall be
submitted by the Chief of the Division of Inspections or his/her representative
to the Planning Commission for their approval.  If the application and the plan
are approved by the Planning Commission, the Chief of the Division of
Inspections or his/her representative, Chief of Fire and Chief of Police, the
Director of Public Safety shall issue a license on payment of the proper fee.
   (b)   The application for a license shall be rejected if the report
submitted thereon shows that the game room sought to be licensed does not
comply with the health and fire regulations applicable thereto.
(Ord. 1981-077.  Passed 5-12-81.)
755.04  LICENSE FEE; RENEWAL.
   Any person, firm, corporation or association to which a license is granted
shall pay an annual fee of fifty dollars ($50.00).  The fee for any new license
issued after July 1 shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
   Upon receipt of an application for renewal, the Director of Public Safety
shall cause an inspection to be made of the premises to determine compliance to
the safety and fire regulations and the requirements of this chapter.  Upon
proof of compliance, the Director of Public Safety shall renew the license upon
payment of the annual fee.
   All licenses granted under the provisions of this chapter shall expire on
January 21.  The license shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the game
room for which it was issued.  No transfer of any license shall be permitted.
(Ord. 2007-053.  Passed 5-22-07.)
755.05  INTERIOR REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   The interior of the game room shall provide a minimum area per
amusement device equal to the size of the amusement device plus one foot of
area on each side of the amusement device plus an area of four feet in front of
each amusement device.
   (b)   The interior of the game room shall also contain sufficient toilet
facilities as required and defined by the provisions of the Ohio Basic Building
Code which are in effect at the time that application for a license is made.
(Ord. 1981-077.  Passed 5-12-81.)
755.06  SUPERVISION.
   Each operator of a game room shall provide a responsible adult supervisor
having attained the age of twenty-one years for each ten amusement devices or a
fraction thereof that may be located on the game room premises.  The supervisor
shall maintain the decorum of the game room by keeping the aisle way free for
passage throughout the game room and shall further control the amount of noise.
(Ord. 1981-077.  Passed 5-12-81.)
755.07  HOURS.
   The hours of operation of the game room shall be during normal business
hours relative to that particular business.
(Ord. 2007-054.  Passed 5-22-07.)
755.08  LICENSE REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION.
   The Director of Public Safety, upon recommendation of the Chief of the
Division of Inspection or his/her representative, Chief of Fire, or Chief of
Police, may at any time revoke or suspend licenses granted under authority of
this chapter for the failure to comply with the terms of this chapter or any
rules of the State, and in addition thereto, the Director of Public Safety
shall have the full power and authority to revoke the license of any firm,
person or corporation or association convicted of a felony.
(Ord. 1981-077.  Passed 5-12-81.)
755.99  PENALTY.
   Any firm, person, corporation or association who violates any provision of
this chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor for each offense.
(Ord. 1981-077.  Passed 5-12-81.)
CHAPTER 757
Toxic Waste Disposal
757.01   Prohibiting disposing of toxic waste.
757.99   Penalty.
757.01  PROHIBITING DISPOSING OF TOXIC WASTE.
   No person, firm or corporation shall dump, bury or dispose of in any manner
any type of toxic material, including but not limited to, toxic waste and
radioactive waste materials on public or private properties within the
boundaries of the City.
(Ord. 1986-051.  Passed 4-22-86.)
757.99  PENALTY.
   After notification, any person, firm or corporation who violates any
provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a first degree misdemeanor as
defined in Section
501.99.
(Ord. 1986-051.  Passed 4-22-86.)

Massage Establishments and Technicians

759.99   Violation and penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Massage parlors and practitioners - see Ohio R.C. 4731.10 et seq.
759.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of enforcing this chapter, the following words are defined
and shall have the meanings ascribed to them as hereinafter set forth:
   (a)   "City" means the City of Eastlake, Ohio.
   (b)   "Employee" means any person over eighteen years of age, other than a
massager, who renders any service in connection with the operation of a massage
establishment and receives compensation from the operator of the establishment
or from patrons.
   (c)   "Licensee" means the person certified by the State Medical Board and
to whom the City has issued a license to own or operate a massage establishment
as defined herein.
   (d)   "Massage" means any method of pressure on, or friction against, or
stroking, kneading, rubbing, tapping, pounding, vibrating or stimulating of the
external parts of the human body with the hands or with the aid of any
mechanical electrical apparatus or appliances with or without such
supplementary aids as rubbing alcohol, liniments, antiseptics, oils, powder,
creams, lotions, ointment or other such similar preparations commonly used in
the practice of massage, under such circumstances that it is reasonably
expected that the person to whom the treatment is provided, or some third
person on his or her behalf, will pay money or give any other consideration or
any gratuity therefor.
   (e)   "Massage establishment" means any establishment having a source of
income or compensation derived from the practice of massage as defined herein
and which has a fixed place of business where any person, firm, association or
corporation engages in, or carries on, any of the activities as defined herein.
   (f)   "Massager", "masseur" or "masseuse" means any person also known as a
masseur or masseuse who, for any consideration whatsoever, engages in the
practice of massage.
   (g)   "Outcall massage service" means any business, the function of which is
to engage in, or carry on, massages at a location designated by the customer or
client rather than at a massage establishment.
   (h)   "Patron" means any person over eighteen years of age or older who
receives a massage under such circumstances that it is reasonably expected that
he or she will pay money, or give any other consideration therefor.  Any person
under eighteen years of age who receives a massage under such circumstances
that it is reasonably expected he or she will pay money, or give any other
consideration therefor, and who is referred for the massage by the written
prescription of a licensed medical doctor.
   (i)   "Permittee" means the person to whom a permit has been issued to act
in the capacity of a massager.
   (j)   "Person" means any individual, partnership, firm, association, joint
stock company, corporation or combination of individuals of whatever form or
character.
   (k)   "Recognized school" means any school or educational institution
licensed to do business as a school or educational institution in the State; or
any school recognized by or approved by the State and approved or affiliated
with the American Massage and Therapy Association, Inc.; and, which has for its
purpose, teaching of the theory, method, profession or work of massage; which
school requires a resident course of study of not less than seventy hours
before the student shall be furnished with a diploma or certificate of
graduation from the school or institution following completion of the course.
   (l)   "Sexual or genital area" means genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus or
perineum of any person, or the vulva or breasts of a female.
      (Ord. 1987-028.  Passed 1-27-87.)
759.02  LICENSE OR PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (a)   Establishment License Required.  No person shall engage in, or carry
on, the business of massage unless he has a valid massage establishment license
issued by the City pursuant to the provisions of this chapter for each and
every separate office or place of business conducted by such person.
   (b)   Massager's Permit Required.  No person shall practice massage as a
massager, employee or otherwise, unless he:
      (1)   Has been examined and certified by the State Medical Board to
practice massage; or
      (2)   Has a valid and subsisting massager's permit issued to him by the
City pursuant to the provisions of this chapter.
         (Ord. 1987-028.  Passed 1-27-87.)
759.03  EXEMPTIONS.
   This chapter shall not apply to the following individuals while engaged in
the personal performance of the duties of their respective professions:
   (a)   Physicians, surgeons, chiropractors, osteopaths or physical therapists
who are duly licensed to practice their respective professions in the State.
   (b)   Nurses who are registered under the laws of the State.
   (c)   Barbers and beauticians who are duly licensed under the laws of the
State, except that this exemption shall apply solely to massaging of the neck,
face, scalp and hair of the customer or client for cosmetic or beautifying
purposes
      (Ord. 1987-028.  Passed 1-27-87.)
759.04  APPLICATION FOR MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENT LICENSE.
